2. All members of commissions, boards, or other units operated by and under the
jurisdiction of the village;
3. All employees and all persons who perform a service on a volunteer basis for the
village and under its direction and control and any persons providing services to
the village under any mutual aid or similar agreement;
4. Police and fire pension boards, their trustees, commissioners and public officials;
and
5. Employees and public officials of the village serving on the board of any
independent governmental or intergovernmental or not for profit organization, in
which the village has an affiliation, upon the following conditions; service on the
board is approved by the village and furthers the interest of the village shall be
indemnified, defended and held harmless by the village from and against all
liabilities, for compensatory damages, expenses of investigation, judgments and
amounts paid in settlement which may be imposed upon or reasonably incurred or
paid by such official or employee in connection with or resulting from any claim
made against him/her, or any action, suit proceeding or investigation in which
he/she may be involved, by reason of his/her being or having been such officials or
such employee of the village and acting within the scope of his/her employment or
official duties.
B. Additional Rights: The foregoing rights of indemnification shall be in addition to any
other rights to which such official or employee may be entitled as a matter of law.
C. Civil Or Criminal Matters: The benefits of this section shall not apply to civil matters
where the individual is the plaintiff or moving party or where it shall be finally
adjudicated in any action, suit, or proceeding that said individual shall not have acted
in good faith and in a reasonable belief that his/her action was in the best interest of
the village. Said benefit shall not apply in any criminal matter or proceeding.
D. Counsel Provisions: The village shall handle the defense of any appropriate cause of
action by the corporation counsel of the village, or by other counsels, at the discretion
of the village. The designation of defense counsel by the village shall not preclude such
defense being conducted under a reservation of rights of indemnity by the village. In
the event the cause of action is covered under a policy of insurance of the village or
through membership in a self-insurance pool, which insurance or pool provides for
defense, it shall be discretionary in the village as to whether legal counsel is
designated by the village to assist in defense. In circumstances involving litigation or
other legal proceeding between two (2) persons qualifying for the privileges granted
herein, the corporation counsel will not be required to represent or otherwise
participate on behalf of either party.
E. Additional Counsel Provisions: Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit
any such individual from seeking additional legal counsel other than that provided by
the village. However, nothing herein shall be construed as to require the village to pay
any fees or other expenses incurred as a result of employment of such additional
counsel. (Ord. 79-34, 8-27-1979; amd. Ord. 99-20, 6-14-1999; Ord. 01-53, 11-26-2001)
F. Officials Affected By Policy: The rights and benefits of this chapter shall include, but not
be limited to, the following individuals: Village President, Village Trustees, village
administrator, assistant village administrator, Village Clerk, corporation counsel,
treasurer and finance director, health officer, director of public works, building
commissioner, fire chief, police chief, village planner, director of economic
development, village prosecutor, member of the board of environmental health,
member of the board of fire and police commissioners, member of the zoning board of
appeals, member of the plan commission, director of family and senior services, village
engineer, member of other boards or commissions. (Ord. 79-34, 8-27-1979; amd. Ord.
99-20, 6-14-1999; Ord. 01-53, 11-26-2001; Ord. 05-54, 12-12-2005)
1-8-15: VILLAGE RIGHTS OF SUBROGATION:
When an employee suffers injury or death under circumstances creating a legal liability for
damages on the part of a third party other than the village, it is recognized that the injured
employee or his/her personal representative may bring legal proceedings against the third
party for damages. In such case, if the action against the third party is brought by the injured
employee or his/her personal representative and judgment is obtained and paid, or settlement
is made with the third party, either with or without suit, then from the amount received by the
employee or personal representative, there shall be paid to the village the amount of
compensation paid or to be paid by the village or on behalf of the village by a self-insurance
pool in which the village is a member, to the employee or personal representative during the
period of injury (or upon death), including, but not limited to, amounts paid or to be paid from
village funds such as salary, workers' compensation benefit, insurance deductibles, selfinsurance
payments including group health plan payments or fringe benefits.
The above mentioned right of subrogation in favor of the village, as employer, shall be in
addition to any other rights the village may otherwise have under applicable law.
This policy shall be administered as provided for in those sections of the personnel manual
pertaining to rights of subrogation. (Ord. 97-40, 10-13-1997)
1-8-16: POLICY ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT:
It is unlawful to harass a person because of that person’s sex. The courts have determined
sexual harassment is a form of discrimination under Title VII of the U.S. Civil Rights Act of
1964, as amended in 1991. All persons have a right to work in an environment free from
sexual harassment. Sexual harassment is unacceptable misconduct which affects individuals
of all genders and sexual orientations. It is a policy of the Village of Morton Grove to prohibit
harassment of any person by any municipal official, municipal agent, municipal employee, or
municipal agency or office on the basis of sex or gender. All municipal officials, municipal
agents, municipal employees, and municipal agencies or offices are prohibited from sexually
harassing any person, regardless of any employment relationship or lack thereof.
A. Definition of Sexual Harassment: This policy adopts the definition of sexual harassment
as stated in the Illinois Human Rights Act, which currently defines sexual harassment
as any unwelcome sexual advances or requests for sexual favors or any conduct of a
sexual nature when:
1. Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or
condition of an individual’s employment, or
2. Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for
employment decisions affecting such individual, or
3. Such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an
individual’s work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive
working environment.
Conduct which may constitute sexual harassment includes:
1. Verbal: sexual innuendos, suggestive comments, insults, humor, and jokes about
sex, anatomy or gender-specific traits, sexual propositions, threats, repeated
requests for dates, or statements about other employees, even outside of their
presence, of a sexual nature.
2. Non-verbal: suggestive or insulting sounds (whistling), leering, obscene gestures,
sexually suggestive bodily gestures, “catcalls”, “smacking” or “kissing” noises.
3. Visual: posters, signs, pin-ups or slogans of a sexual nature, viewing pornographic
material or websites.
4. Physical: touching, unwelcome hugging or kissing, pinching, brushing the body,
any coerced sexual act or actual assault.
5. Textual/Electronic: “sexting” (electronically sending messages with sexual content,
including pictures and video), the use of sexually explicit language, harassment,
cyber stalking and threats via all forms of electronic communication (e-mail,
text/picture/video messages, intranet/on-line postings, blogs, instant messages and
social network websites like Facebook and Twitter).
The most severe and overt forms of sexual harassment are easier to determine. On the
other end of the spectrum, some sexual harassment is more subtle and depends, to
some extent, on individual perception and interpretation. The courts will assess sexual
harassment by a standard of what would offend a “reasonable person.”
B. Procedure for Reporting an Allegation of Sexual Harassment: An employee who either
observes sexual harassment or believes herself/himself to be the object of sexual
harassment should deal with the incident(s) as directly and firmly as possible by clearly
communicating her/his position to the offending employee, and her/his immediate
supervisor. It is not necessary for sexual harassment to be directed at the person
making the report. Any employee may report conduct which is believed to be sexual
harassment, including the following:
1. Electronic/Direct Communication. If there is sexual harassing behavior in the
workplace, the harassed employee should directly and clearly express her/his
objection that the conduct is unwelcome and request the offending behavior stop.
The initial message may be verbal. If subsequent messages are needed, they
should be put in writing in a note or a memo.
2. Contact with Supervisory Personnel. At the same time direct communication is
undertaken, or in the event the employee feels threatened or intimidated by the
situation, the problem must be promptly reported to the immediate supervisor of
the person making the report, a department head, a director of human resources,
an ethics officer, the city manager or administrator, or the chief executive officer of
the municipality.
The employee experiencing what he or she believes to be sexual harassment must not
assume the employer is aware of the conduct. If there are no witnesses and the victim
fails to notify a supervisor or other responsible officer, the municipality will not be
presumed to have knowledge of the harassment.
3. Resolution Outside Municipality. The purpose of this policy is to establish prompt,
thorough and effective procedures for responding to every report and incident so
problems can be identified and remedied by the municipality. However, all
municipal employees have the right to contact the Illinois Department of Human
Rights (IDHR) or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) for
information regarding filing a formal complaint with those entities. An IDHR
complaint must be filed within 180 days of the alleged incident(s) unless it is a
continuing offense. A complaint with the EEOC must be filed within 300 days.
Documentation of any incident may be submitted with any report (what was said or done,
the date, the time, and the place), including, but not limited to, written records such as
letters, notes, memos, and telephone messages.
All allegations, including anonymous reports, will be accepted and investigated regardless
of how the matter comes to the attention of the Village. However, because of the serious
implications of sexual harassment charges and the difficulties associated with their
investigation and the questions of credibility involved, the claimant’s willing cooperation is
a vital component of an effective inquiry and an appropriate outcome.
C. Prohibition on Retaliation for Reporting Sexual Harassment Allegations: No municipal
official, municipal agency, municipal employee, or municipal agency or office shall take
any retaliatory action against any municipal employee due to a municipal employee’s:
1. Disclosure or threatened disclosure of any violation of this policy, or
2. The provision of information related to or testimony before any public body
conducting an investigation, hearing, or inquiry into any violation of this policy, or
3. Assistance or participation in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of this policy.
For the purposes of this policy, retaliatory action means the reprimand, discharge,
suspension, demotion, denial of promotion or transfer, or change in the terms or
conditions of employment of any municipal employee that is taken in retaliation for a
municipal employee’s involvement in protected activity pursuant to this policy.
No individual making a report will be retaliated against even if a report made in good faith
is not substantiated. In addition, any witness will be protected from retaliation.
Similar to the prohibition against retaliation contained herein, the State Officials and
Employees Ethics Act (5 ILCS 430/15-10) provides whistleblower protection from
retaliatory action such as reprimand, discharge, suspension, demotion, or denial of
promotion or transfer that occurs in retaliation for an employee who does any of the
following:
1. Discloses or threatens to disclose to a supervisor or to a public body an activity,
policy, or practice of any officer, member, agency, or other Village employee, the
Village employee reasonably believes is in violation of a law, rule, or regulation, or
2. Provides information to or testifies before any public body conducting an
investigation, hearing, or inquiry into any violation of a law, rule, or regulation by
any officer, member, agency, or other employee, or
3. Assists or participates in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of the State
Officials and Employees Ethics Act.
Pursuant to the Whistleblower Act [740 ILCS 174/15(a)], an employer may not retaliate
against an employee who discloses information in a court, an administrative hearing, or
before a legislative commission or committee, or in any other proceeding, where the
employee has reasonable cause to believe the information discloses a violation of a state
or federal law, rule, or regulation. In addition, an employer may not retaliate against an
employee for disclosing information to a government or law enforcement agency, where
the employee has reasonable cause to believe the information discloses a violation of a
state or federal law, rule, or regulation. [740 ILCS 174/15(b)].
According to the Illinois Human Rights Act (775 ILCS 5/6-101), it is a civil rights violation
for a person, or for two or more people to conspire, to retaliate against a person because
he/she has opposed that which he/she reasonably and in good faith believes to be sexual
harassment in employment, because he/she has made a charge, filed a complaint,
testified, assisted, or participated in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under the
Illinois Human Rights Act.
An employee who is suddenly transferred to a lower paying job or passed over for a
promotion after filing a complaint with IDHR or EEOC, may file a retaliation charge – due
within 180 days (IDHR) or 300 days (EEOC) of the alleged retaliation.
D. Consequences of a Violation of the Prohibition on Sexual Harassment: In addition to
any and all other discipline that may be applicable pursuant to municipal policies,
employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/or a collective
bargaining agreement, any person who violates this policy or the Prohibition on Sexual
Harassment contained in 5 ILCS 430/5-65, may be subject to a fine of up to $5,000 per
offense, applicable discipline or discharge by the municipality and any applicable fines
and penalties established pursuant to local ordinance, state or federal law. Each
violation may constitute a separate offense. Any discipline imposed by the municipality
shall be separate and distinct from any penalty imposed by an ethics commission and
any fines or penalties imposed by a court of law, or a state or federal agency.
E. Consequences for Knowingly Making a False Report: A false report is a report of sexual
harassment made by an accuser using the sexual harassment report to accomplish
some end other than stopping sexual harassment or retaliation for reporting sexual
harassment. A false report is not a report made in good faith which cannot be proven.
Given the seriousness of the consequences for the accused, a false or frivolous report
is a severe offense that can itself result in disciplinary action. Any person who
intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this policy
shall be subject to discipline or discharge pursuant to applicable municipal policies,
employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks, and/or collective
bargaining agreements.
In addition, any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any
provision of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act to an Ethics Commission, an
Inspector General, the State Police, a State’s Attorney, the Attorney General, or any other
law enforcement official is guilty of a Class A misdemeanor. An Ethics Commission may
levy an administrative fine of up to $5,000 against any person who intentionally makes a
false, frivolous or bad faith allegation.
(Ord. 18-02, 01-08-18)
1-8A: VILLAGE DEPARTMENT DIRECTORS
1-8A-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A. The following provisions shall apply to the following Department Directors:
Village Administrator
Corporation Counsel
Finance Director/Treasurer
Building Commissioner
Director of Community and Economic Development
Director/Superintendent of Public Works
Police Chief
Fire Chief
Assistant Village Administrator
B. Appointment: Department directors shall be appointed by the president with the
consent of the board of trustees in December of each year and shall serve for the
following calendar year.
C. Removal: The president, with the consent of the board of trustees may remove a
department director prior to the end of his/her annual term for cause.
D. Vacancy. In the event of a vacancy, the president by and with the consent of the board
of trustees shall appoint a successor who shall serve until the end of the calendar year.
E. Interim or temporary vacancy. If for any reason a department director is absent or is
unable to fulfill his/her duties, the Village Administrator may assume or delegate said
responsibilities or authorities until the department director can resume his/her duties,
or a successor is appointed. If the village administrator is unable to perform his/her
duties, the president shall designate a department director to act as village
administrator pro-tem who shall have all the powers and duties of the village
administrator until the village administrator can resume his/her duties or a successor is
appointed.
F. Other Duties. In addition to those authorities and responsibilities set forth in this code,
the village administrator and each department director shall also have such
responsibilities and shall perform such duties as authorized by state statute, village
ordinances, resolutions, or as assigned by the village administrator or president.
G. Compensation. A department director’s compensation shall be determined by the
village administrator and approved by the corporate authorities from time-to-time,
provided, however, the salary may be increased, but not diminished during the term
the department director was appointed.
1-8A-2: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
A. Residency. Within twelve months after first being appointed, the village administrator
shall become a resident of the village of Morton Grove, or shall reside within 15 miles
of the village.
B. Powers and Duties. The village administrator shall be responsible for the day-to-day
administration of the village and of its affairs. The administrator shall have power and
be required to devote his/her entire and exclusive time to the discharge of his/her
official duties, including:
1. Direct and supervise all departments: The administrator shall direct, supervise, and
coordinate the administration of all departments, offices, and agencies of the
village including supervising the activities of department directors and insuring all
municipal services and programs are efficiently and effectively managed, except as
otherwise provided by law.
2. Employ and discharge of all employees: The administrator shall employ, and when
necessary for the good of the service, suspend or remove all employees of the
village except department directors and administrative officers appointed by the
village president and board of trustees, all board and commission members and
those employees over which, by ordinance or statute, the village administrator and
corporate authorities have no such authority. Prior to his/her taking any such
action, the administrator shall consult with the head of the department under
consideration and the village president. The administrator shall also be responsible
for the conduct of all collective bargaining processes within the village and shall
make recommendations to the village board regarding collective bargaining
agreements for consideration and approval by the board. The administrator shall,
subsequent to approval, be responsible for administering all collective bargaining
agreements reached through the collective bargaining process.
3. Preparation of Budget/Budget Officer: The administrator, in cooperation with the
director of finance/treasurer shall prepare an annual operating and capital budget
which shall include a five (5) year capital improvements program (CIP) which shall
be submitted to the corporate authorities for their review and consideration and
shall prepare a budget adoption ordinance which shall be placed on the agenda for
board consideration prior to the start of each fiscal year. The administrator shall
also be responsible, in conjunction with the director of finance/treasurer, for the
administration of the adopted budget and capital improvement program.
4. Financial Reports: Prepare and submit to the corporate authorities in conjunction
with the director of finance/treasurer reports on finances which shall include
amounts budgeted and the amounts spent, showing the unexpended budgeted
items and amounts, and shall keep the corporate authorities advised of the
financial condition and future needs of the village.
5. Tax levy ordinance and abatement resolutions: The village administrator, in
conjunction with the director of finance/treasurer, shall cause the tax levy
ordinance and any necessary abatement resolutions to be prepared and placed on
the board agenda for consideration by the corporate authorities in a timely manner
so the levy ordinance and any abatement resolutions can be acted upon and a
certified copy of the tax levy ordinance and any abatement resolutions properly
filed with the county clerk within the time frames prescribed by law.
6. Property custody and inventory: The village administrator in conjunction with the
director of finance shall maintain an inventory of all fixed assets owned by the
village and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all village property
which is not by law or ordinance otherwise assigned to some other officer or person
for care and control.
7. Administrative recommendations: The administrator shall make written or verbal
recommendations to the corporate authorities for the adoption of such measures or
policies as the administrator may deem necessary and expedient for the
improvement of the village and its administration.
8. Board of trustees' agenda preparation: The administrator, with the approval of the
mayor, shall prepare an agenda for each meeting of the corporate authorities
which shall contain those matters to be considered at the meeting.
9. Board of trustees' meeting attendance: The administrator shall attend all meetings
of the corporate authorities, unless excused there from. The village administrator
shall be entitled to take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the
corporate authorities but shall have no right to vote.
10. Administrative complaints, enforcement: The administrator shall see all laws and
ordinances are duly enforced and investigate into the affairs of the village or any
department or division thereof. He shall investigate all complaints in relation to all
matters concerning the administration of the village and in regard to service
maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits
and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed.
11. Publication of documents: The administrator shall publish all ordinances, maps and
other documents and instruments required by law to be published where
publication is by printing in a book or pamphlet form the printing shall contain the
legend "Published by Authority of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village
of Morton Grove, Illinois" and the date of publication. The provision of duplicated
copies of the document either bound or unbound shall be deemed to satisfy this
requirement.
12. Purchase and contract authority: Unless directed otherwise by the village code or
the corporate authorities, the administrator may approve and be responsible for all
purchases and contracts for services and supplies as provided in chapter 9 of this
Code, and may execute contracts or agreements for the purchase or goods or
services or to settle or resolve disputes for amounts less than $20,000.
13. General responsibility: Perform such other duties as may be required of him/her by
the corporate authorities, not inconsistent with village ordinances and laws. (Ord.
72-26, 9-5-1972; amd. Ord. 01-53, 11-26-2002)
1-8A-3: CORPORATION COUNSEL:
A. Wherever in any statute of the state of Illinois or ordinances of the village of Morton
Grove the words "village attorney" are used, the same is hereby made applicable to
the corporation counsel.
B. Powers and duties. The Corporation Counsel shall have full charge of all of the law
business of the village including the following:
1. Ordinances and resolutions. The Corporation Counsel shall draft or approve all
ordinances and resolutions.
2. Leases by, bond approval: The corporation counsel shall draft or review drafts of all
contracts, leases, deeds and other papers connected with any department of the
village and approve all bonds as to form.
3. Written opinions: The corporation counsel shall, when required, furnish written
opinions upon subjects submitted for review by the board of trustees or by the
village administrator or any department director.
4. Freedom of information and open meetings officer. The corporation counsel shall
be responsible for ensuring the village complies with the Open Meetings and
Freedom of Information Act and shall be designated as the Freedom of Information
and Open Meetings Act officer.
5. Litigation and prosecutions. The corporation counsel shall be responsible for all
litigation where the village is a party or has a duty to defend a party, and all
prosecutions of village ordinances.
6. Supervision of special counsel. The corporation counsel shall make
recommendations to the village administrator and the corporate authorities
regarding the hiring of special counsel including prosecutors, and shall supervise
their assignments and work.
1-8A-4: FINANCE DIRECTOR/TREASURER:
A. Bond. Before beginning his/her duties, the finance director/ treasurer shall execute to
the village a bond conditioned for the faithful discharge of his/her duties with sureties
to be approved by the president and board of trustees, and said bond shall be not less
than ten percent (10%) of the highest amount of real estate taxes received by the
village (Ord. 01-53, 11-26-2001)
B. Powers and duties.
1. Supervise employees. The finance director/treasurer, under the supervision of the
village administrator, shall exercise control and supervision over all employees
assigned to the department of finance, and to exercise general supervision with
regard to all village officers and employees charged in any manner with the
receipt, collection or disbursement of village revenue or with the collection and
return of village revenue into a treasury.
2. Treasury maintained: The finance director/treasurer shall receive all monies
belonging to the village and shall periodically render a statement when requested
by the corporate authorities, setting forth all the money received, and on what
account they shall have been received; also all monies paid out and on what
account they shall have been paid. The finance director/treasurer shall prepare and
cause to be filed with the corporate authorities an annual financial report required
by the state of Illinois Compiled Statutes.
3. Accounts kept: The finance director/treasurer shall keep by double entry, a full and
detailed account of all village funds, general tax receipts and receipts from other
sources. He/she shall also keep a bond account and sinking fund account in the
village ledger and books of account, in such manner as to accurately show all
monies received by the village from whom and on what account they shall have
been received; also all monies paid out by the village and on what account they
have been paid. Said books shall be kept in such manner as to be readily
understood and investigated; which books and all papers and files of said office
shall at all times be open to the examination of the president and board of
trustees, or any member thereof.
4. Warrant's register: The warrant register shall be prepared by the director,
approved by the village administrator, and reviewed by the trustee liaison before
being submitted to the corporate authorities for approval. The finance
director/treasurer shall upon payment of any voucher or warrant cancel the same,
and mark same "paid" with the date of each payment.
5. Reports: The finance director/treasurer shall, upon request file a written financial
report with the village administrator and the corporate authorities. Said written
report shall contain an accurate financial statement of the fiscal affairs of the
village as of the date that report is being rendered.
6. Director to serve as village collector: The finance director/treasurer shall serve as
the village collector and shall perform all of the duties and have all of the powers of
that office.
1-8A-5: BUILDING COMMISSIONER:
A. Powers and duties.
1. The building commissioner, under the supervision of the village administrator, shall
manage, control, and exercise general supervision over the department of building
and inspectional services together with the staff thereof.
2. Forms: The building commissioner shall generate applications and forms for all
work requiring a building permit or approval by the building department.
3. Permits issued: The building commissioner shall receive all applications and
documentation that shows and describes any proposed work, review these
submittals for compliance, and shall issue permits for land usage, construction,
alteration, repair, removal, and occupancy of structures.
4. Enforcement and inspections: The building commissioner shall enforce all laws and
ordinance provisions relating to buildings, property maintenance, subdivisions,
zoning, and related work and require inspections are made of all permitted work as
frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with all applicable laws and
ordinances, and shall cause the issuance of occupancy certificates or ensure the
approval of final inspections.
5. Forwarding of permits: The building commissioner shall forward to the township
assessor and county assessor a report summarizing all building permits and
occupancy certificates issued within thirty (30) days of the end of the month when
such permits are issued. Each copy shall include the permit number and address of
each property.
6. Interpret Regulations: The building commissioner shall interpret the rules and
regulations relative to proper erection, construction, alteration, repair, removal,
use, occupancy, and maintenance of structures and adjoining property.
7. Official records of applications: The building commissioner shall keep official
records of applications received, permits issued, certificates issued, inspection
reports, copies of notices and orders issued, as well as all codes, rules and
regulations that have been adopted.
8. Reports: The building commissioner shall periodically, as required by the village
administrator, provide a comprehensive report of all matters pertaining to the
department of building and inspectional services.
9. Supervise employees: The building commissioner, under the supervision of the
village administrator, shall exercise control and supervision over all employees
assigned to the building department.
1-8A-6: DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT:
A. Powers and duties.
1. Economic development: The director of community and economic development
shall be responsible for managing the village's economic development program
including the recruitment and retention of business and industry.
2. Economic development assistance programs: The director of community and
economic development, in conjunction with the director of finance/treasurer, shall
be responsible for the administration of economic development financial assistance
programs.
3. Administration of TIF districts: The director of community and economic
development, in conjunction with the village administrator and director of
finance/treasurer, shall be responsible for the administration of all tax increment
financing (TIF) districts established by the village board and for coordinating the
various redevelopment activities undertaken within those TIF districts.
4. Comprehensive planning: The director of community and economic development
shall be responsible for the coordination of planning functions within the village
and shall maintain the comprehensive plan of the village.
5. Special planning and economic development studies: The director of community
and economic development shall initiate and coordinate the preparation of special
studies, subarea plans, and the provision of information on the physical, social, and
economic characteristics of the village and its individual neighborhoods as may be
required by the village board, the plan commission or any other agency
participating in community planning or economic development efforts.
6. Community growth and development: The director of community and economic
development shall advise and make recommendations to the village administrator,
the plan commission, and the village president and board of trustees on matters
related to the growth and development of the village.
7. Administration of project review: The director of community and economic
development, in conjunction with the building commissioner and village engineer,
shall be responsible for overseeing the project review process and the coordination
of reviews by all relevant village departments for projects which require variations,
special use permits, PUDs and/or otherwise necessitate relief from or approvals
through the zoning board of appeals or board of trustees, through the plan
commission.
8. Amendments to the unified development code: The director of community and
economic development, in conjunction with the building commissioner and village
engineer, shall be responsible for recommending changes to the unified
development code (title 12) based on development trends, market demands,
adopted comprehensive and subarea plans, and/or policy directives established by
the village president and board of trustees.
9. Supervise employees: The community and economic development director, under
the supervision of the village administrator, shall exercise control and supervision
over all employees assigned to the community and economic development
department.
1-8A-7: DIRECTOR/SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
A. Powers and duties:
1. The director of public works, under the supervision of the village administrator,
shall have charge of the maintenance and repair of all public works owned and/or
maintained by the village, including operation of the water distribution system,
reservoirs, mains, hydrants and other appurtenances thereto, along with public
streets, rights-of-way, sanitary and storm sewers.
2. The director shall also oversee the division of engineering and be responsible for
the development of plans and the supervisors of construction for all public
improvement projects undertaken by the village.
3. Applications reviewed: The director of public works shall review all applications
submitted to him by the plan commission, zoning board of appeals, or department
of building and inspectional services to determine the impact upon the village's
sewer system, water distribution system and other public works, and shall report
his/her findings to the appropriate authority as provided in this code.
4. Maintenance of public works: The superintendent of public works shall have charge
of the construction, repair and maintenance of the streets and sidewalks, sewers,
water lines and other public works of the village.
5. Public improvement program: The director of public works shall provide advice and
recommendations for new equipment, capital projects and other public
improvements.
6. Employee supervision: All employees assigned to the maintenance or operation of
the water plant and to the street and sewer maintenance division shall be under
the supervision and direction of the superintendent of public works.
1-8A-8: POLICE CHIEF:
A. Powers and duties.
1. The chief of police shall be the ranking officer of the department; he shall be
responsible for preserving peace and order in the Village while protecting the
rights of persons and property. The chief of police, under the supervision of the
village administrator, shall be responsible for the performance of the police
department and all of its functions.
2. The chief of police shall review law enforcement related matters and manage the
operational effectiveness and efficiency of the department.
3. The chief of police shall prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct and
guidance of the members of the department as he shall deem advisable and such
rules shall be binding on such members. It shall be the duty of every member of
the department to conduct himself or herself in a proper and law abiding manner
at all times, and shall obey the orders and directions of the chief of police or his/her
designee.
4. The chief of police and the members of the police department shall have the
powers of arrest and detention as set out in the Illinois statutes in such cases made
and provided and shall bear the responsibility for enforcement of all criminal,
quasi-criminal statutes and village ordinances.
5. The chief of police and the members of the police department may investigate any
and all matters, submitted or discovered, to determine the impact upon the village
and its law enforcement program. He shall report his findings to the appropriate
authority as provided in this code or to state and federal authorities.
6. The chief of police shall be keeper of the village jail, and shall have custody of all
persons incarcerated therein and keep accurate records pertaining to the custody
of persons.
7. The chief of police shall provide for the custody, care and control of lost,
abandoned or stolen property and shall keep accurate records pertaining to the
custody of such property.
8. The chief of police shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the
activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance.
9. The chief of police will maintain certification and training as appropriate to current
laws, standards, and levels of service as provided under state statue( 50 ILCS
705/10.7).
1-8A-9: FIRE CHIEF:
A. Powers and duties.
1. The fire chief shall serve as the village’s fire marshal.
2. The fire chief, under the supervision of the village administrator, shall be
responsible for the performance of the fire department, of all of its functions and
obligations as assigned by ordinance or other action of the corporate authorities.
3. Right of entry, inspections: The fire chief, or anyone duly authorized by him, is
hereby empowered as the authority having jurisdiction (AHJ) for interpretation and
enforcement of adopted codes and standards; to enter any building or premises for
the purpose of making inspections or code evaluations and to serve written notice
upon the owner or occupant to abate, within any specified time, any and all fire
and/or life safety hazards that may be discovered. This authority shall extend to
the issuance of citations when authorized by this code.
4. Records and reports: The fire chief shall see that complete and accurate records
are kept on all fires, inspections, apparatus and equipment and other pertinent
activities of the department, and shall submit annual reports to the village
administrator for transmittal to the president and board of trustees.
5. Restrict fire or hazardous area limits: The fire chief or other officer in command
may prescribe limits in the vicinity of a fire or hazardous area within which no
person excepting those who reside therein, firefighters, paramedics, policemen,
officers of the municipality, and those admitted by any officer of the fire
department shall be permitted to go.
6. Removal of property: The fire chief or other officer in command, shall have power
to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the
preservation of said property from fire or hazardous situation or to prevent the
spreading of fire or the hazardous condition, or to protect adjoining properties.
7. Destruction of buildings: The fire chief, or in his/her absence, the officer in
command may direct the tearing down and removal of any building, structure, or
barrier for the purpose of mitigating or eliminating a fire or hazardous condition.
8. Review of application: The fire chief or his/her designee shall review all applications
submitted to him by the plan commission, zoning board of appeals or department
of building and inspectional services to determine whether or not there will be
compliance with the village's fire prevention code.
9. Investigations: The fire chief and his/her designated representatives are hereby
empowered to investigate all fires, explosions or other hazardous conditions and to
exercise all rights and duties provided by state statute and municipal ordinance
with regard to completing such investigations.
10. Emergency medical services: It shall be the responsibility of the fire chief and
his/her designated representatives to ensure the effective provision of emergency
medical services, including paramedic aid and ambulance transportation services
as authorized by the corporate authorities.
11. Certification to be current: It shall be the responsibility of the fire chief or his/her
representative to maintain certification and training as appropriate to current laws,
standards, and levels of service. (Ord. 95-25, 7-17-1995; amd. Ord. 01-53,
11-26-2001)
1-8A-10: ASSISTANT VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
A. Powers and duties:
1. The supervision and administrative control of the department as directed by the
village administrator. The assistant administrator shall perform such other duties
as may from time-to-time be assigned to him by the village administrator.
2. Assisting and advising the village administrator in the performance of all duties and
responsibilities of the office of the village administrator.
3. Act as the director of human resources for the village.
4. In the absence of the village administrator, the assistant village administrator shall
have the authority to sign any agreement, contract, personnel transaction,
purchase or communication that may also be signed by the village administrator.
5. Keeping the village administrator informed of all matters and conditions which
have any bearing upon the municipal services or upon the village government.
6. Assisting in directing and coordinating the services provided by all departments,
units, and offices in the village.

Chapter 9
MUNICIPAL FINANCES
1-9A: PURCHASING PROCEDURES
1-9A-1: PURCHASING AUTHORITY:
The village administrator is hereby appointed purchasing agent for the village of Morton
Grove. As purchasing agent, the village administrator shall maintain a purchasing manual
outlining in detail purchasing procedures not inconsistent with this ordinance and purchasing
forms to be utilized by all village officials and employees.
1-9A-2: APPROVAL OF PURCHASES:
All purchase orders or contracts must be for goods or services covered by a category in the
budget for the current fiscal year as approved by the president and board of trustees or
approved by a 2/3 majority of the corporate authorities. Village Board approval is required for
any purchase or contract for services expected to exceed $20,000, except for emergency
purchases or services or products or services covered by blanket purchase orders or contracts
previously approved by the village board. The corporate authorities may approve multi-year
contracts, even if the term of the contract may exceed the term of any or all member of the
corporate authorities, provided the contract may be cancelled in succeeding years due to
unavailability of funds, or at the discretion of the corporate authority with not more than 60
days advance notice. No contract may provide for automatic (i.e. without village board
approval) extensions.
1-9A-3: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
No employee shall participate directly or indirectly in any purchase or bidding process if he
knows that he or a member of his/her immediate family is a bidder, has a financial interest
equal or greater than a 10% ownership interest in a bidder, or stands to obtain a financial
benefit from the bidding process. Any contract awarded in violation of this ordinance shall be
deemed void.
1-9A-4: COMPETITIVE PURCHASING REQUIREMENTS:
No purchases or contracts for services or goods of any kind or description, payment for which
is to be made from funds of the village, shall be made by the purchasing agent or any officer,
employee or agent of the village except in the manner hereafter set forth in this chapter.
A. Competitive Bidding Requirements:
1. Purchases Up to Two Thousand Dollars: Whenever any contemplated purchase or
contract for goods or services is for a sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or
less, the purchasing agent may order the items as needed without further
formality.
2. Goods or Services Costing More than Two Thousand Dollars but less than Ten
Thousand Dollars: Whenever any contemplated purchase or contract is for goods or
services costing more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) but less than ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00), the purchasing agent shall obtain at least three (3)
quotations to be obtained from qualified vendors for the goods or services to be
purchased. The quotations may be obtained orally and the award for purchase or
contract given to the lowest responsible bidder.
3. Purchases Costing more than Ten Thousand Dollars but less than Twenty Thousand
Dollars: Whenever any contemplated purchase or contract is for goods or services
costing more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) but less than twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00), the purchasing agent shall solicit at least three (3)
written quotations for the item or items to be purchased. The quotation shall be
submitted in written form to the purchasing agent who shall award the purchase or
contract to the lowest responsible bidder.
4. Purchases Costing Twenty Thousand Dollars or more: Except as provided in Section
B below, the following bidding process shall be followed whenever any
contemplated purchase or contract for goods or services is for the sum of twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more:
a. A notice inviting bids shall be posted on the Village’s website at least ten (10)
business days inclusive prior to the date set for the receipt of the bids. The
notice herein required shall include a general description of the articles to be
purchased or services performed and the time and place for opening bids. In
addition, the purchasing agent may distribute the notice to prospective,
responsible bidders and bidding outlets and utilize other methods of
advertisement in order to increase the number of responsible bidders.
b. All bids shall be submitted sealed to the village official designated in the bid
packet or electronically if required or allowed by the purchasing agent and shall
be clearly identified as a bid on the envelope or electronic transmission,
c. All bids shall be opened in public at a time and place stated in the public
notices.
d. A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted on the Village’s website and in
the village hall.
e. The purchasing agent may reject any and all bids and parts of all bids and
readvertise or resolicit bids whenever it is deemed to be in the best interest of
the village. (Ord. 93-7, 2-8-1993)
B. Exceptions to Competitive Bidding Requirements: The competitive bidding process set
forth above shall not apply to the following circumstances; however, except in
emergencies, such purchases and contracts are subject to approval by the village
board if the total price or cost is expected to exceed twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00):
1. Sole Source Vendor: A sole source vender provides an item or service, which is
deemed by the village administrator to be unique, have features, specifications or
will provide a superior utility not obtainable from similar products, or not
reasonably available in a competitive market. A preference for a particular brand
does not constitute a sole source.
2. Professional Services: Professional service providers include without limitation
physicians, attorneys, engineers, certified public accountants or planners shall be
selected utilizing a qualifications-based process. Price shall be considered as an
important but not necessarily a deciding factor.
3. Whenever any contemplated purchase or contract for goods or services is to be
funded with motor fuel tax, state or federal funds and there exist superseding
purchasing requirements imposed by statute, the bidding procedures will conform
to statutory requirements.
4. Cooperative Purchasing: It may be deemed advantageous from time to time to
purchase goods or services under the cooperative procurement program sponsored
by the state of Illinois or any other governmental jurisdiction or intergovernmental
agreement.
5. The competitive bidding process, or any part of this article may be waived by a 2/3
vote of the corporate authorities.
C. Bid Protest Procedure: Any bidder wishing to file a protest regarding the bidding
process may do so by giving written notice to the purchasing agent within three days
of the posting of the award of the bid. This notice should include the title of the bidding
invitation, the bidding opening date and the nature of the protest. A protest review
board comprised of the village administrator, finance director and the originating
department director or his/her designee shall investigate the protest within 10
business days after receipt. The board may request additional information or testimony
from the protester or other necessary persons. The board shall furnish a written
decision to the protesting party within 10 days after concluding its investigation. The
board shall have the authority to reject all bids and/or void the purchase or contract
award if warranted by its investigation.
1-9A-5: DETERMINING LOWEST RESPONSIBLE BIDDER:
The purchasing agent shall review and investigate all bids to determine the lowest responsible
bidder, and shall award all or part of the purchase or contract or, where applicable, to make a
recommendation to the village board regarding the award to the lowest responsible bidder. In
determining the lowest responsible bidder, the purchasing agent shall consider:
A. The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the
services required;
B. Whether the bidder can perform the contract to provide the services promptly or within
required time periods without delay or interference;
C. The quality of performance of previous or existing contracts or services, including
compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances of the state of Illinois and the
village of Morton Grove;
D. Whether the bidder is or has been prohibited from doing business with the state of
Illinois or the United States of America;
E. The financial resources and the ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide
the service;
F. The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or services.
If all factors above other than price are deemed to be equal, the purchasing agent shall
determine the lowest responsible bidder to be a local business whose price is within 5% or
$15,000 whichever is lower of the lowest responsible bidder. A local business is one where the
requested product or service is provided, made or distributed from a vender whose business is
located within the corporate limits of the Village of Morton Grove.
1-9A-6: PERFORMANCE BOND:
The purchasing agent in making contracts for public work of any kind costing over $5,000 to
be performed for the village shall require every contractor for the work to furnish, supply and
deliver a bond to the village entering into the contract with good and sufficient sureties. The
amount of the bond shall be one hundred percent (100%)of the contract amount, one hundred
twenty-five percent (125%) of an architect’s or engineer’s opinion of probably cost or
otherwise for such amount that he may deem sufficient to secure the best interests of the
village, and the bond, among other conditions, shall be conditioned for the completion of the
contract, for the payment of material used in the work and for all labor performed in the work,
whether by subcontractor or otherwise.
1-9A-7: EMERGENCY PURCHASES:
In case of an emergency that requires immediate purchase of supplies or services and time is
of the essence, the village administrator shall be empowered to authorize the purchase or to
secure the services needed without complying with the procedures as set forth in this chapter.
A full report in writing of the circumstances requiring an emergency purchase shall be
submitted to the Corporate Authorities as soon as practical whenever an emergency purchase
is made.
1-9A-8: CHANGE ORDERS:
A change order is a revision of the contract term, other than as specifically provided for in the
contract, which authorizes an addition, deletion, or revisions in the work or necessitates an
increase or decrease in the cost of the contract or time of completion. All change orders must
be in writing and approved by the purchasing agent. Change orders which require an
additional cost or expense to the village of $20,000 or more must be approved by the
corporate authorities.
1-9A-9: TRAVEL REGULATIONS AND REIMBURSEMENT:
The village administrator with the approval of the finance director is authorized to reimburse
officials and employees of the village for expenses incurred when traveling on official village
business. Expenses reimbursed shall be limited to the direct costs, including registration fees,
transportation, lodging costs and other direct expenses related to attendance. The cost of all
meals and other miscellaneous travel expenses incurred shall be reimbursed on a per diem
basis as established from time-to-time by the Village administrator and finance director.
Except in emergencies or for good cause, reimbursement for travel and related expenses
must be preapproved.
1-9B: PURCHASE AND SALE OF SURPLUS AND REAL PROPERTY
1-9B-1: SALE OF SURPLUS PROPERTY:
A. Obsolete or surplus personal property which is, in the opinion of the finance director
and the village administrator, is no longer necessary or useful to the village, and that
has an estimated value exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and all motor
vehicles and real property of any value of the village of Morton Grove shall be sold
subject to approval by resolution of a simple majority of the Village Board of Trustees.
B. Obsolete or surplus personal property other than motor vehicles which are, in the
opinion of the village administrator and finance director, determined no longer
necessary or useful to the village, which has an estimated value of less than one
thousand dollars ($1,000), may be sold at the direction of the village administrator
upon consultation with the finance director and the appropriate department director in
a manner deemed appropriate considering the value of the asset, and the amount of
staff time necessary for the sale of said property.
C. Obsolete or surplus personal property which is determined to be no longer necessary
or useful to the village by the village administrator and finance director, and which, in
the opinion of the village administrator has no substantial resale or trade-in value, may
be disposed of or recycled in the reasonable discretion of the village administrator
after consultation with the finance director and appropriate department director.
D. All obsolete personal property may also be traded-in for credit on the purchase of other
property at the discretion of the village administrator upon consultation with the
finance director and appropriate department director.
E. The village administrator shall provide a report, at least annually, to the village board
regarding the disposal of obsolete or surplus property.
1-9B-2: PURCHASE OF REAL ESTATE:
A. The corporate authority may by resolution or ordinance passed by a 2/3-majority
purchase or lease real estate for public purposes.
B. Prior to the purchase or lease of real estate, the Village Administrator may, but is not
required to obtain one or more appraisals of the property.
C. Purchases of real estate may be paid through installments to be made at stated
intervals during a certain period of time.
D. An ordinance or resolution approving the lease or purchase of real estate shall be
posted and shall be made available for public inspection upon reasonable request.
E. This section is an exercise of the Village’s home rule authority and shall, to the extent
allowed by law, supersede all state laws and regulations in conflict herewith.
1-9B-3: SALE OF REAL ESTATE:
A. The corporate authority may by resolution or ordinance passed by a 2/3 majority
convey real estate if it finds the real estate is no longer necessary, appropriate,
required for the use of, profitable to, or in the best interests of the village.
B. The village shall seek proposals, bids or qualifications in a manner deemed appropriate
by the village administrator for a period of at least thirty (30) days prior to the passage
of any resolution or ordinance approving the conveyance or sale of real estate.
C. Prior to conveying or selling Village owned real estate, the Village Administrator may,
but is not required to obtain one or more appraisals of the property.
D. The Village may accept the highest qualified bid or any other bid determined to be in
the best interest of the municipality by a vote of 2/3 of the corporate authorities, or
may reject any and all bids by a majority vote.
E. The corporate authority may by resolution or ordinance passed by a simple majority
donate or give away real estate if it finds it has no actual value, or may be or become a
liability or may need to be torn down.
F. The corporate authority may by resolution or ordinance passed by a simple majority
convey, sell, purchase, accept or otherwise transfer real estate from or to another unit
of government.
1-9C: FUNDS
1-9C-1: POLICEMENS' PENSION FUND:
A. Established: There shall be a police pension fund established in the municipality as
provided by law1.
B. Board, Terms: The board of trustees of the said fund shall consist of five (5) members,
two (2) appointed by the Village President and two (2) elected by the members of the
police department, and one elected by the beneficiaries of the pension fund. The
elections shall be held on the third Monday in April, and the term of each member shall
be two (2) years. Said term shall end on the second Tuesday in May, provided that one
of the first two (2) such trustees appointed by the president shall serve for a term of
one year. The pension board shall meet at least quarterly as provided by law, and shall
hold such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the pension board.
C. Revenues For Fund: There shall be deposited in the pension fund the sums required by
law, which shall include the legally mandated employee deduction made from the
salary of each member of the police force and all revenues and earnings from the
investments of the fund.
1-9C-2: FIREMENS' PENSION FUND2:
A. Established: There is hereby established a firemens' pension fund, in accordance with
chapter 40 of the Illinois statutes.
B. Board: The board of trustees of the firemens' pension fund shall be appended in
accordance with said chapter 40.
C. Revenues, Administration: The contributions, the reserves and the general
administration of said fund shall be all in accordance with the aforesaid statutes of the
state of Illinois. (1969 Code § 32.265)
1-9C-3: FOREIGN FIRE TAX FUND:
A. Foreign Fire Tax Board:
1. There shall be established a board known as the Morton Grove foreign fire tax
board (MGFFTB). The MGFFTB shall consist of seven (7) trustees, the fire chief, who
shall hold office by virtue of rank, and six (6) members, who shall be elected
biannually by the sworn members of the department (3 to be elected in years
ending in even numbers and 3 to be elected in years ending in odd numbers).
2. The trustees of the MGFFTB shall serve without compensation and shall be subject
to all state and local ethics laws and ordinances.
3. The finance director/treasurer of the village or his/her designee shall serve as an
ex-officio member of the MGFFTB. The finance director shall receive notice of and
participate in all meetings; however, he or she shall not be entitled to vote.
4. All members of the department shall be eligible to be elected as officers of the
foreign fire tax board. The members of the MGFFTB shall annually elect a
chairperson, secretary, and treasurer from among the trustees. The treasurer of
the MGFFTB shall give a sufficient bond to the municipality in which the fire
department is organized. This bond shall be approved by the Village President,
conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his/her duties under
the ordinance and the rules and regulations provided for in this chapter and in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1.
5. All meetings of the MGFFTB shall be in compliance with the Illinois open meetings
act. Dates and times of meetings shall not conflict with assignable time as
designated by the current collective bargaining agreement. The secretary of the
MGFFTB shall cause minutes to be recorded at all meetings. Minutes of all
meetings will be filed with the Village Clerk.
6. The MGFFTB shall promulgate rules and bylaws governing the internal operations
of the board. Such rules and bylaws shall include, but not be limited to, the board
election process, rules for meetings, internal procedures for establishing budget
and purchase requests. Said rules and bylaws shall be in compliance with this
section and all other applicable federal, state and village contracts, ordinances,
purchasing procedures and other regulations. The secretary of the MGFFTB shall
submit a copy of the rules/bylaws, and any subsequent amendments to the Village
Clerk.
B. Designated Account: The treasurer of the MGFFTB will immediately forward all tax
funds received pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 et seq., and/or title
4, chapter 12, article C of this code to the finance director/treasurer of the village who
shall:
1. Deposit the funds into an account designated for the exclusive use of the MGFFTB
to be expended only as provided in this chapter and 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-10-1 et seq. Funds remaining in the account at the end of a village fiscal year
shall accumulate in the account for future allocation.
2. Maintain the financial accounting for all deposits and expenditures pertinent to the
account, and provide the MGFFTB a quarterly accounting of receipts and
expenditures of the account.
3. Ensure the service charge levied by the Illinois Municipal League (IML) for the
collection of the tax has been remitted to the IML from the tax funds received.
4. Cause all receipts and expenditures in the foreign fire tax fund to be audited
annually as part of the village's overall audit process. The audit will also verify all
expenditures from the account are for the maintenance, use, and benefits of the
fire department.
C. Budget: The MGFFTB shall approve and submit an annual budget request to the fire
chief for his/her review no later than July 1 of each year. Under no circumstances shall
the budget provide for the expenditure of funds:
1. For the personal benefit of or to directly compensate any person;
2. For food or beverages;
3. For travel expenditures of any kind;
4. In a manner associated with any politically affiliated or organized labor
organization or to fund any litigation or legislative activity;
5. To fund investments or speculative ventures designated to produce profit;
6. To produce employee/retiree compensation contrary to current federal or state
regulations;
7. In a manner to encumber additional cost or administrative workload for the village.
The fire chief will work through the MGFFTB in order to amend budget requests as appropriate
and incorporate the MGFFTB budget request into the annual budget request to the village
board on behalf of the fire department. The village board will approve the MGFFTB budget
request so long as sufficient funds are provided for the requested expenditures in the
designated account and the expenditures are in compliance with this chapter.
D. Expenditures: The MGFFTB may authorize and direct the finance director/treasurer of
the village to purchase items or make expenditures from the designated account. All
purchases made from the account shall become the property of the village. All
purchases must:
1. Not require funds in excess of those currently available in the designated account;
2. Be in full compliance with current village purchasing procedures;
3. Be appropriated in the annual budget approved by the MGFFTB and the village
board;
4. Be preapproved by the MGFFTB by a majority vote in a meeting subject to the
Illinois open meetings act. A tie vote will be considered as rejection of the request.
5. Be preapproved by the fire chief if the purchased items are intended to be used, or
reside, on fire department apparatus, on village property, or within the fire
stations. In addition, the fire chief must approve the physical location of any
purchased item or service pertinent to the aforementioned locations.
E. Limitations: Nothing in this section shall give the MGFFTB any function or purpose not
specifically stated in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 et seq. At no time will the
actions of the MGFFTB interfere/detract or increase the duties, responsibilities, or rights
of the fire chief, village administrator, village board, or the fire and police commission
of Morton Grove. The MGFFTB actions will not impede the usual and customary
operation of the fire department. (Ord. 10-10, 5-10-2010)
1-9D: MUNICIPAL BUDGET
1-9D-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF FISCAL YEAR:
The calendar year is the fiscal period and the municipality's budget, financial statements and
comprehensive annual financial report shall all be prepared to reflect financial activities based
upon an operating period of January 1 through December 31 of each year. (Ord. 97-53,
11-10-1997)
1-9D-2: ADOPTION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The village hereby adopts 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 through 5/8-2-9.9 to provide
that an annual budget be prepared by the budget officer and adopted by the corporate
authorities prior to the start of the fiscal year in lieu of an annual appropriations ordinance. In
the event of an inconsistency between the above statutes and village ordinances, village
ordinances will be controlling. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-3: BUDGET OFFICER:
The budget officer shall be the village administrator as designated by the Village President
and approved by the corporate authorities by the adoption of this article. The budget officer
shall cause the annual budget to be prepared and submitted to the corporate authorities for
review and consideration. The budget officer shall have all the powers and duties currently
enumerated in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-2-9.2, powers and duties of budget officer,
and/or such subsequent amended powers and duties as may be added by the general
assembly from time-to-time. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-4: PREPARATION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
The budget officer shall compile a budget pursuant to the above referenced sections of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes as they are now and/or may hereinafter be amended containing
projections of beginning fund balances, estimates of revenue available during the fiscal period
along with recommended expenditures for the municipality. The budget shall be submitted to
the board of trustees at least thirty (30) days prior to the start of the fiscal period and shall be
reviewed by the board and adopted prior to January 1 of each year. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-5: PUBLIC INSPECTION, NOTICE AND HEARING ON BUDGET:
Copies of the proposed annual budget shall be posted on the village website and made
available for public inspection in the office of the village administrator and at the Morton
Grove public library for a period of at least ten (10) days prior to approval of the adopted
budget; further, there shall be a public hearing on the proposed budget not less than one
week after posting of the proposed annual budget as set forth in this section and prior to the
time the final budget is adopted.
1-9D-6: REVISIONS TO THE ANNUAL BUDGET:
The corporate authorities may from time-to-time amend an adopted annual budget by a vote
of two-thirds (2/3) of its members to delete, add, change or create new subclasses within any
of the funds, departments, or activities incorporated within the annual budget. No revision of
the budget shall be made unless sufficient funds are available either within current fund
balances or from new revenue or other financing sources to meet expenditure requests
included in the proposed budget amendment. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-7: BUDGET TRANSFERS BETWEEN DEPARTMENTS:
Transfers between departments and from reserve or contingency accounts may be made at
any time when the approval thereto of two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the corporate
authorities then holding office in the manner required by law. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-8: BUDGET TRANSFERS WITHIN DEPARTMENTS:
The budget officer may authorize transfers between individual line accounts within a
department or activity budget upon receipt of a written request and recommendation from
the appropriate department director. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)
1-9D-9: BUDGET REPORTS:
It shall be the responsibility of the budget officer to have prepared a detailed budget report on
a quarterly basis which shall be distributed to all department directors as well as the
corporate authorities. (Ord. 97-53, 11-10-1997)

Chapter 10
TAXATION
1-10A: LOCAL IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND
RESPONSIBILITIES
1-10A-1: TITLE:
This article shall be known as, and may be cited as, the Locally Imposed and Administered
Rights and Responsibility Ordinance. (Ord. 01-02, 12-11-2000)
1-10A-2: SCOPE:
The provisions of this article shall apply to the village of Morton Grove's procedures in
connection with all of the village's locally imposed and administered taxes. (Ord. 01-02,
12-11-2000)
1-10A-3: DEFINITIONS:
Certain words or terms herein shall have the meaning ascribed to them as follows:
ACT: The "local government taxpayers' bill of rights act".
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The village of Morton Grove's president and board of trustees.
LOCAL TAX ADMINISTRATOR: The village of Morton Grove is charged with the administration
and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes, including staff, employees or
agents to the extent they are authorized by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax
administrator's stead. The local tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the
terms of this article to give full effect to this article. The exercise of such authority by the local
tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this article and the act.
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX OR TAX: Each tax imposed by the village that is
collected or administered by the village not an agency or department of the state. It does not
include any taxes imposed upon real property under the property tax code or fees collected
by the village other than infrastructure maintenance fees.
NOTICE: Each audit notice, collection notice or other similar notice or communication in
connection with each of the village's locally imposed and administered taxes.
TAX ORDINANCE: Each ordinance adopted by the village that imposes any locally imposed and
administered tax.
TAXPAYER: Any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and
generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax is placed and with
respect to consumer taxes includes the business or entity required to collect and pay the
locally imposed and administered tax to the village.
VILLAGE: The village of Morton Grove, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 01-02, 12-11-2000)
1-10A-4: NOTICES:
Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the notice is to be in
writing mailed not less than seven (7) calendar days prior to the day fixed for any applicable
hearing, audit or other scheduled act of the local tax administrator. The notice shall be sent by
the local tax administrator as follows:
A. First class or express mail, or overnight mail, addressed to the persons concerned at
the persons' last known address, or
B. Personal service or delivery. (Ord. 01-02, 12-11-2000)
1-10A-5: LATE PAYMENT:
Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made to the village pursuant to
any tax ordinance shall be considered late unless it is: a) physically received by the village on
or before the due date, or b) received in an envelope or other container displaying a valid,
readable U.S. postmark dated on or before the due date, properly addressed to the village,
with adequate postage prepaid, or paid electronically with funds posted to the village’s
account on or before the due date. (Ord. 01-02, 12-11-2000)
1-10A-6: PAYMENT:
Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in the following order: a)
first to the tax due for the applicable period; b) second to the interest due for the applicable
period; and c) third to the penalty for the applicable period. (Ord. 01-02, 12-11-2000)
1-10A-7: CERTAIN CREDITS AND REFUNDS:
A. The village shall not refund or credit any taxes voluntarily paid without written protest
at the time of payment in the event that a locally imposed and administered tax is
declared invalidly enacted or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction.
However, a taxpayer shall not be deemed to have paid the tax voluntarily if the
taxpayer lacked knowledge of the facts upon which to protest the taxes at the time of
payment or if the taxpayer paid the taxes under duress.
B. The statute of limitations on a claim for credit or refund shall be four (4) or less years
after the end of the calendar year in which after payment in error was made. The
village shall not grant a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes,
interest, or penalties to a person who has not paid the amounts directly to the village.
C. The procedure for claiming a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered
taxes, interest or penalties paid in error shall be as follows:
1. The taxpayer shall submit to the local tax administrator in writing a claim for credit
or refund together with a statement specifying:
a. The name of the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim;
b. The tax period for the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the
claim;
c. The date of the tax payment subject to the claim and the cancelled check or
receipt for the payment;
d. The taxpayer's recalculation, accompanied by an amended or revised tax
return, in connection with the claim; and
e. A request for either a refund or a credit in connection with the claim to be
applied to the amount of tax, interest and penalties overpaid, and, as
applicable, related interest on the amount over paid; provided, however, that
there shall be no refund and only a credit given in the event the taxpayer owes
any monies to the village.
2. Within ten (10) days of the receipt by the local tax administrator of any claim for a
refund or credit, the local tax administrator shall either:
a. Grant the claim; or
b. Deny the claim in whole or in part, together with a statement as to the reason
for the denial or the partial grant and denial.
1-10A-8: AUDIT PROCEDURE:
Any request for proposed audit pursuant to any local administered tax shall comply with the
notice requirements of this article.
A. Each notice of audit shall contain the following information:
1. The tax;
2. The time period of the audit; and
3. A brief description of the books and records to be made available for the auditor.
B. Any audit shall be conducted during normal business hours and if the date and time
selected by the local tax administrator is not agreeable to the taxpayer, another date
and time may be requested by the taxpayer within thirty (30) days after the originally
designated audit and during normal business hours.
C. The taxpayer may request an extension of time to have an audit conducted. The audit
shall be conducted not less than seven (7) days nor more than thirty (30) days from
the date the notice is given, unless the taxpayer and the local tax administrator agreed
to some other convenient time. In the event taxpayer is unable to comply with the
audit on the date in question, the taxpayer may request another date within the thirty
(30) days, approved in writing that is convenient to the taxpayer and the local tax
administrator.
D. Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the taxpayer's business or
activities, including original source documents and books of entry denoting the
transactions which had given rise or may have given rise to any tax liability, exemption
or deduction. All books shall be kept in the English language and shall be subject to
and available for inspection by the village.
E. It is the duty and responsibility of every taxpayer to make available its books and
records for inspection by the village. If the taxpayer fails to provide the documents
