10-12-5: TESTS FOR COMPLIANCE:
Whenever there is insufficient evidence of compliance with the provisions of this chapter, or
evidence that any material or any construction does not conform to the requirements of this
chapter, or in order to substantiate claims for alternate materials or methods of construction,
the enforcing authority may require tests as proof of compliance. These tests are to be made
at the expense of the owner by an agency approved by the enforcing authority. If there are no
appropriate test methods specified in this chapter, the enforcing authorities shall determine
the test procedure. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-12-6: ALTERNATE CONSTRUCTION METHOD, MATERIAL:
The provisions of this chapter are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method
of construction not specifically prescribed by this chapter, provided such alternate has been
approved by the enforcing authority.
The enforcing authority may approve any such alternate, provided he finds that the proposed
design will satisfactorily perform its intended function and that the material, method or work
will be at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this chapter in quality, strength,
effectiveness, durability and safety. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-12-7: SECURITY FACILITY REQUIREMENTS FOR BUILDINGS:
A. Accessible Windows:
1. Accessible windows shall be of a rated burglar resistant glazing material.
2. If the window is of the type to be opened, it shall be secured with a locking
mechanism capable of withstanding a force of three hundred (300) pounds applied
in any direction.
3. Louvered windows, except those above the first story, shall not be permitted.
4. Outside hinges on all accessible windows shall be provided with nonremovable pins
and/or steel dowels projecting one-half inch (1/2") from one plate into the opposite
plate of the hinge.
5. Window Protection:
a. Windows shall be so constructed that when the window is locked it cannot be
lifted from the frame.
b. Window locking devices shall be capable of withstanding force of three hundred
(300) pounds applied in any direction.
c. Sliding glass windows shall meet or exceed the Architectural Aluminum
Manufacturers Association standards as set forth in their bulleting AAMA
1302.3-1971.
d. Louvered windows, except those above the first story shall not be permitted.
B. Roof Openings:
1. All skylights, hatchways and air duct or air vent openings exceeding eight inches
by twelve inches (8" x 12") on the roof or exterior walls shall be secured.
2. All openings exceeding eight inches by twelve inches (8" x 12") shall have installed
an alarm system. The alarm shall be of the audible type enunciator, or any
combination of:
a. Local Alarm - Audible Only On The Premises: This type shall only be used on
premises located in areas with responsible persons living in the vicinity. Any
excessive noise for an unreasonable length of time shall be declared a
nuisance.
b. Proprietary Alarm: A monitored alarm by a private guard force, available to
respond to any alarm.
c. Central Station Alarm: A monitored alarm in a specially designed monitoring
facility offering services to individual subscribers, i.e., police notification.
d. Police Department Alarm: a monitored alarm by the local or nearby law
enforcement agency which initiates direct police response1.
C. Doors:
1. Sliding Glass Doors:
a. Sliding glass doors shall meet or exceed the Architectural Aluminum
Manufacturers Association standards as set forth in their bulletin AAMA
1303.3-1971.
b. All single sliding doors shall have the movable section of the doors sliding on
the inside of the fixed portion of the door.
c. Sliding glass doors shall be equipped with locking devices and shall be so
installed that the doors cannot be moved in any direction or lifted from the
track when the doors are in the locked position.
2. Garage Doors: Whenever parking facilities are provided either under or within the
confines of the perimeter walls of any multiple dwelling, such facility shall be fully
enclosed and provided with a locking device.
3. Entrance Doors To Individual Units:
a. In hotels, motels and multiple-family dwellings, locks on entrance doors to
individual units shall have dead bolts with one inch (1") minimum throw and
hardened steel inserts in addition to a dead latch. The locks shall be so
constructed that both dead bolt and dead latch can be retracted by a single
action of the inside knob.
b. All doors shall be of solid core with minimum thickness of one and three-fourths
inch (13/4").
c. Vision panels in individual entrance doors or within forty inches (40") of the
inside activating device shall be of rated burglar resistant glazing material.
d. An interviewer, or door scope, shall be provided in each individual unit entrance
door which does not contain a vision panel.
e. Doors swinging out shall have nonremovable hinge pins and/or steel dowel
projecting a minimum of one-half inch (1/2") from one plate into the opposite
hinge of the plate.
f. In-swinging doors shall have rabbited jambs.
g. Jambs for all doors shall be so constructed or protected as to prevent violation
of the function of the strike. The strike plate shall be of hardened steel
construction, a minimum of three and one-half inches (31/2") in length of which
the screw length shall be sufficient to extend one inch (1") into the stud directly
adjacent to the door frame.
h. Cylinder guards shall be installed on all rim type cylinder locks whenever the
cylinder projects beyond the face of the door or is otherwise accessible to
griping tools.
I. Door frame shall be of steel or wood and be so reinforced as to prevent
spreading.
D. Illumination: all multiresidential buildings with common entrances to more than one
unit shall be illuminated with at least a 100-watt bulb. Such bulb shall be covered and
protected by a polycarbonate cover or cover of equal breaking resistant material. (Ord.
85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-12-8: SECURITY REQUIREMENTS FOR SPECIFIC BUILDINGS, USES:
A. Commercial Buildings:
1. Exterior Doors: Any building required by present building code2 to have panic
proof hardware locks on exit doors shall be exempt from the exterior door locking
security hereunder.
a. A single door shall be secured with either a double cylinder or single cylinder
dead bolt without a turn piece with a minimum throw of one inch (1"). Any dead
bolt must contain hardened material to repel attempts at cutting through the
bolt.
b. On pairs of doors, the active leaf (door) shall be secured with the type lock
required for single doors in subsection A1a of this section. The inactive leaf
shall be equipped with throw bolts or flush bolts at top and bottom with
minimum throw of five-eighths inch (5/8"). The throw bolt must be hardened
material. The active leaf shall have a full length astragal secured to the opening
edge.
c. All doors which require locking at top and bottom shall be secured with throw
bolts at both top and bottom with a minimum throw five-eighths inch (5/8"). The
throw bolt must be hardened material.
d. Cylinders shall be so designed or protected with cylinder guards.
e. Exterior sliding commercial entrances shall be secured with throw bolts at the
top and bottom.
f. Rolling overhead doors, solid overhead doors, sliding or accordion garage type
doors, exterior doors only, shall be secured with a cylinder lock or padlock on
the inside, when not otherwise controlled or locked by electrical power
operation. If a padlock is used on the inside, when not otherwise controlled or
locked, it shall be of hardened steel shackle, with a minimum 5-pin tumbler
operation with nonremovable key when in an unlocked position.
g. Metal accordion grate or grill type doors shall be equipped with metal lock
guide track at top and bottom, and a cylinder lock and/or padlock with
hardened steel shackle and minimum 5-pin tumbler operation with
nonremovable key when in an unlocked position. The bottom track shall be so
designed that the door cannot be lifted from the track when the door is in the
locked position.
h. Outside hinges on all exterior doors shall be provided with nonremovable
pins when using pin type hinges, and the center hinge shall have a steel dowel
projecting a minimum of one-twelfth inch (1/12") from one plate into the opposite
plate of the hinge.
I. Doors with glass panels shall be secured as follows:
(1) Rated burglary resistant glass or glass like material, or
(2) Iron or steel grills of at least one-eighth inch (1/8") material of two inch (2")
mesh secured on the inside of the glazing.
j. In-swinging doors shall have rabbited jambs.
k. Wood doors, not of solid core construction, or with panels therein with less than
one and three-fourths inch (13/4") thickness, shall be covered with at least 16-
gauge sheet metal or its equivalent, attached with screws on minimum six inch
(6") centers.
l. Jambs for all doors shall be constructed or protected so as to prevent violation of
the function of the strike.
m. All exterior doors excluding front doors shall have a minimum of 100-watt
bulbs over the outside of the door. Such bulb shall be protected with a
polycarbonate cover or cover of equal breaking resistant material.
n. All door frames shall be made of steel or wood and be so reinforced as to
prevent the spreading of strike plates, on all doorways. The strike plate shall be
of hardened steel construction, a minimum of three and one-half inches (31/2")
in length of which the screw length shall be sufficient to extend one inch (1")
into the stud directly adjacent to the door frame.
2. Safes: Commercial establishments having one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or
more in cash on the premises after closing hours shall lock such money in a class
TRTL30 safe, as defined by Underwriters' Laboratories, after closing hours. The
class TRTL30 rating is the minimum allowable rating for safes.
B. Office Buildings, Multiple Occupancy: Each entrance door on individual offices shall be
of the solid core type and have dead bolt locks with a minimum one inch (1") throw
which can be opened with a thumb turn or combination dead latch and dead bolt with
single action retraction of inside knob.
C. Multiple Dwellings, Minimum Standards: Exterior doors and doors leading from garage
areas into multiple dwelling buildings and doors leading onto stairwells, except in
hotels and motels, shall be equipped with self-closing devices, allowing egress to the
exterior of the building or into the garage area, or stairwell, but requiring a key to be
used to gain access to the interior of the building from the outside or garage area or
stairwell, and this lock shall be a mortise type or similar type with bolt type action.
D. Private Dwellings, Minimum Standards:
1. Exterior swing doors and doors leading from a garage into private dwellings shall
be of solid core no less than one and three-fourths inches (13/4") in thickness.
2. Exterior swing doors and doors leading from a garage into a private dwelling shall
be equipped with a dead lock with a minimum one inch (1") throw and a dead
locking latch. Dead bolts shall contain hardened inserts or equivalent, so as to
repel cutting tool attack. The locks shall be so constructed that both dead bolt and
dead latch can be retracted by a single action of the inside knob.
3. Vision panels or sidelights in exterior doors or within forty inches (40") of the inside
activating device must be of rated burglar resistant glazing material.
4. Exterior doors swinging out shall have nonremovable hinge pins and/or steel
dowels projecting a minimum of one-half inch (1/2") from one plate into the opposite
plate of the hinge.
5. In-swinging doors shall have rabbited jambs.
6. Jambs for all doors shall be constructed or projected so as to prevent a violation of
the functions of the strike. The strike plate shall be one hardened steel
construction, a minimum of three and one-half inches (31/2") in length of which the
screw length shall be sufficient to extend one inch (1") into the stud directly
adjacent to the door frame.
7. Cylinder guards shall be installed on all locks whenever the cylinder locks project
beyond the face of the door or is otherwise accessible to gripping tools.
8. An interviewer or door scope shall be provided in each entrance door which does
not contain a vision panel. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-12-9: BURGLAR ALARMS:
If it is determined by the enforcing authority of this chapter that the security measures and
locking devices described in this chapter do not adequately secure the building, the
installation and maintenance of an intrusion detection device (burglar alarm system) may be
required and shall be installed. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-12-10: PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve,
remove, convert, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in the village or
cause the same to be done, unless the same is done in conformance with the provisions of
this chapter.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, for each such violation, shall be
punished by a fine in accordance with title 1, chapter 4 of this code. Each day that a violation
is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 08-22, 5-12-2008)
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
Footnote 1: See title 6, chapter 6 of this code.
Footnote 2: See chapter 1 of this title.
Chapter 13
FAIR HOUSING
10-13-1: TITLE, PURPOSE, APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
A. Title: This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the FAIR HOUSING ORDINANCE
OF MORTON GROVE, ILLINOIS. (1969 Code § 156.001; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
B. Purpose And Declaration Of Policy: It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village
of Morton Grove (hereafter referred to as "the village"), and the purpose of this
chapter, in the exercise of the village of its police and regulatory powers for the
protection of the public safety, for the public health, morals, safety and welfare of the
persons in and residing in the village, and for the maintenance and promotion of
commerce, industry and good government in the village, to secure to all persons living
and/or working or desiring to live and/or work in the village a fair opportunity to
purchase, lease, rent or occupy real estate without unlawful discrimination. (1969 Code
§ 156.005; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
Furthermore, it is hereby declared to be the policy of the village that all persons shall
be assured fair and equal treatment under the law. In the area of fair housing, they
shall have their rights protected without unlawful discrimination, regardless of the
actual or perceived status, practice, or expression of their race, color, gender, sexual
orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status,
familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or
any lawful rental payment.
It is further declared to be the policy of the village that no person, group of persons, or
corporations shall attempt to escalate or de-escalate property prices because of any
present or perspective change in the race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age,
creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status,
military status, housing status, matriculation, or the source of income or any lawful
rental payment of persons in the neighborhood of said property.
It is further declared to be the policy of the village that in the spirit of harmony, the
village board and its community relations commission shall endeavor to work with and
cooperate with local realtors, lending institutions, and all other persons to ensure
opportunity for all persons to live in decent housing facilities without unlawful
discrimination because of actual or perceived status, practice or expression of race,
color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation,
or source of income or any lawful rental payment of such persons. Therefore, in order
to effectuate this policy, the following provisions shall prevail.
C. Referral: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit any person from
referring a perspective tenant or purchaser to the community relations commission for
advice and information. Said advice or information may consist of, but is not limited to,
the following:
1. Information regarding the policy of the village to promote equal opportunity in
housing.
2. Information on local, state, and federal equal opportunity programs and
regulations.
D. Construction: This chapter shall be construed according to the fair import of its terms
and shall be liberally construed to further the purposes and policy stated herein and
the special purposes of the particular provision involved. (1969 Code § 156.010; amd.
Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
E. Coverage: Sections 10-13-4 and 10-13-5 of this chapter shall apply, respectively, to
every real estate agent and lending institution who, within the village, performs any
functions as such real estate agent or lending institution but does not maintain an
office or place of business within the village; and said sections 10-13-4 and 10-13-5 of
this chapter shall apply to every real estate agent and lending institution who
maintains an office or place of doing business within the village. The provisions of this
chapter shall not be so construed as to prohibit a real estate broker or real estate
agent on behalf of the owner, from inquiring into and reporting upon qualifications of
any prospective buyer or tenant with respect to limitations or exclusions other than
those of race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing status,
matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment. (1969 Code
§ 156.135; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
F. Severability: If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision of this
chapter to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provision of this chapter
not specifically included in said judgment. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall
adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this chapter to any person or
circumstance, such judgment shall not affect the application of said provision to any
other person or circumstance not specifically included in said judgment. (Ord. 85-1,
1-25-1985)
10-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter:
AGE: As used in this chapter shall be limited to individuals who are at least forty (40) years of
age or older.
ATTORNEY FOR THE COMMITTEE AND COMMISSION: Any attorney, duly licensed by the state
of Illinois, designated by the village board or corporation counsel to act as legal counsel for
the Morton Grove community relations commission and its fair housing committee.
BLOCKBUSTING: No person shall solicit for sale or lease, or list for sale or lease, residential
real property within the village on the grounds of loss of value due to the present or
prospective entry into any neighborhood of any individual or individuals of any particular race,
color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
marital status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of
income or any lawful rental payment.
BOARD OF TRUSTEES: The board of trustees of the village of Morton Grove, Cook County,
Illinois.
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: Nonprofit organization that is supported primarily by charity and
whose principal function is the performance of charitable works or religious activities. This
definition shall include, but not be limited to, churches, mosques, synagogues, or other
religious institutions. Not included in this definition are social organizations and clubs.
COMMISSION: The Morton Grove community relations commission1.
COMMISSION CHAIR: The duly appointed chair of the community relations commission or, in
his/her absence, the designated acting chair.
COMMITTEE: The fair housing committee of the Morton Grove community relations
commission.
COMMITTEE CHAIR: The duly appointed chair of the fair housing committee or, in his/her
absence, the designated acting chair.
COMPLAINANT(S): Person(s) filing a charge of unfair housing practices.
COMPLAINT: A signed notarized statement filed on the complaint form provided by the
commission and available in the office of the village administrator.
CONCILIATION CONFERENCE AND CONCILIATION PANEL (PANEL): A conference held to attempt
to reconcile the parties by resolving the complaint issues in private. A panel of three (3)
commission members who serve on the fair housing subcommittee (title 2, chapter 8 of this
code) including the committee chair, are designated to represent the commission. The village
administrator, assistant village administrator (or the village administrator's designee), the
corporation counsel, and the village trustee appointed as commission liaison will also be in
attendance.
CONCILIATION HEARING AND CONCILIATION HEARING PANEL (PANEL): A hearing held when
reconciliation of the complaint cannot be attained at the conciliation conference. The
committee chair and four (4) other voting members of the commission who serve on the fair
housing subcommittee (title 2, chapter 8 of this code), the village administrator, assistant
village administrator (or the village administrator's designee), the corporation counsel, and
the trustee appointed as commission liaison comprise the conciliation hearing panel.
DISABILITY:
A. A physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of the major
life activities of an individual;
B. A record of such an impairment; or
C. Being regarded as having such an impairment. A person is regarded as having
such a disability under this definition if such a person, as a result of a disability,
requires a support animal such as a guide dog or hearing dog to assist them in a
major life function. Excluded from this definition is an impairment relating to the
illegal use, possession or distribution of "controlled substances" as defined in
schedules I through V of the controlled substances act (21 USC 812).
DISCRIMINATE: To treat any person differently from others because of the person's race, color,
gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital
status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or
any lawful rental payment.
DWELLING: Any building, structure or portion thereof within the village which is used or
occupied, or is maintained, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as a home,
residence, or sleeping place of one or more human beings.
EDUCATIONAL ORGANIZATION: An organization whose uses are related to the functions of
teaching or research, or to the housing, feeding, and care of students and faculty; or
otherwise intended for the primary benefit of students and faculty.
FAMILIAL STATUS: One or more individuals who have not attained the age of eighteen (18)
being domiciled with a parent or another person having legal custody of such individuals, or
the designee of such parent; or the designee of such parent or other person having such
custody with the written permission of such parent or other person. This shall include any
person who is pregnant or is in the process of obtaining legal custody of any individual who
has not attained the age of eighteen (18).
FINDINGS OF FACT: That evidence which demonstrates, makes clear, or ascertains the truth of
the very fact or point at issue. The evidence shall be presented in written form.
HOUSING STATUS: The type of housing in which an individual resides, whether publicly or
privately owned; or an individual's ownership status with respect to the individual's residence;
or the status of having or not having a fixed residence.
LEASE: Includes any sublease, assignment and/or rental, and includes any contract to enter
into any of the foregoing.
LENDING INSTITUTION: Any bank, insurance company, savings and loan association, or other
person in the business of lending or guaranteeing loans, any person in the business of
obtaining, arranging or negotiating loans or guarantees as agent or broker, and any person in
the business of buying or selling loans or instruments for the payment of money which are
secured by title to or a security interest in real estate.
MARITAL STATUS: The legal status of being married, single, separated, divorced, or widowed.
MATRICULATION: The condition of being enrolled in a college or university or other
postsecondary educational institution. It is the intent of this provision to give standing and
protection only to persons enrolled in a college or university or other postsecondary
educational institution.
MILITARY STATUS: The fact of currently serving or having been discharged from the armed
forces of the United States, the reserve components, the national guard or naval militia other
than by a "dishonorable discharge".
NATIONAL ORIGIN: The place in which an individual or one of his or her ancestors was born.
ON A PUBLIC BASIS: The use of any public facility, such as newspaper advertising, real estate
broker services, etc., but does not include a nondiscriminatory sign on the property in
question.
OWNER: Any person who holds legal or equitable title to, or owns any beneficial interest in,
any real property or who holds legal or equitable title to shares of, or holds any beneficial
interest in, any real estate cooperative which owns any real property; or any person who is
acting as the agent, manager, or employee of the owner.
PERSON: An individual, partnership, associations, organizations, corporations, legal
representatives, joint stock companies, mutual companies, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers,
fiduciaries, labor unions or union labor organizations and any other incorporated or
unincorporated organized group that is also an owner, leaser, sublessor, assignor, managing
agent or other individual, firm or corporation having the right to sell, lease or sublease any
dwelling within the village, or any agent, broker or other individual working on behalf of any
individual, firm or corporation. Governmental entities are excluded from this definition.
PRIVATE CLUB ORGANIZATION: An association which may or may not operate out of a building
in which members of a community or association may gather for social, educational, or
cultural activities.
PURCHASE: To acquire by means other than descent or inheritance (e.g., money, labor, barter,
sacrifice); includes any contract to purchase.
QUORUM: The number of voting members which when duly assembled may legally conduct
business. For the purpose of convening a session of the fair housing committee conciliation
hearing, three (3) of the four (4) voting members of the committee must be present.
REAL ESTATE AGENT: Any real estate salesperson licensed in accordance with Illinois
Compiled Statutes, and any other person who, as employee or agent or otherwise, engages in
the management or operation of any real property.
REAL ESTATE BROKER: Any person licensed as a real estate broker in accordance with Illinois
Compiled Statutes, or required thereby to be so licensed.
REAL ESTATE TRANSACTION: The purchase, sale, exchange, or lease of any housing
accommodation or of business, commercial, or industrial property; an option to do any of the
foregoing.
REAL PROPERTY: Any real estate, vacant land, building, or structure within the village limits.
RELIGION: All aspects of religious observance and practice, as well as belief or the actual
identification with or perceived identification with a religion.
RESPONDENT: Person(s) charged with violating any provision of the fair housing ordinance.
SALE: Includes any contract to sell, exchange or to convey, transfer or assign legal or
equitable title to or a beneficial interest in a housing accommodation or a business,
commercial, or industrial property.
SEXUAL ORIENTATION: The status or expression, whether actual or perceived, of
heterosexuality, homosexuality, or bisexuality.
SOURCE OF INCOME: The lawful manner by which an individual supports himself or herself,
and his or her dependents, including, but not limited to, any federal, state, or local public or
medical assistance or any federal, state or local housing subsidies, including rental assistance
or rental supplements.
STEERING: To attempt to discourage or encourage the choice or location of housing of a
prospective purchaser, occupant, or tenant in connection with viewing, buying, leasing, or
occupying real estate, based on race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing
status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment.
TESTIMONY: Statement or statements made by a witness under oath or affirmation.
UNLAWFUL DISCRIMINATION: Discrimination against a person because of the actual or
perceived status, practice or expression of that person's race, color, gender, sexual
orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial
status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental
payment; or the actual or perceived association with such a person.
UNLAWFUL HOUSING PRACTICE(S): One or more acts prohibited by the fair housing ordinance
of the village or as identified in subsection 10-13-6B of this chapter.
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR: The duly appointed chief administrative officer of the village or
his/her designee.
VILLAGE TRUSTEE: A duly elected member of the legislative body (board of trustees) of the
village. One member of the board of trustees is appointed by the village president to act as
liaison to the commission. (1969 Code § 156.020; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. To adopt, promulgate, amend, and rescind rules of procedure consistent with the
provisions of this chapter;
B. To receive and investigate complaints charging discrimination in housing under this
chapter and shall seek conciliation of such complaints and compliance by violators;
C. To hold hearings and make findings of fact with respect to any such complaints;
D. To administer and take sworn testimony;
E. To subpoena witnesses and pertinent documents at the investigation, conciliation
conference, and conciliation hearing stages, which power may be enforced by the
commission by proper petition to any court of competent jurisdiction, if there is reason
to believe that a violation has occurred in the testimony of the witnesses or the
documents or items sought by the subpoena are relevant to the investigation;
F. To hold meetings that are closed to the public for the purpose of conciliating
complaints;
G. To appoint attorneys with expertise in fair housing law with approval by the
corporation counsel and the village board, and have the power to prosecute violations
and represent complaints under this chapter or to otherwise act as would the
corporation counsel;
H. To publish its finding of fact and issue orders in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-4: UNLAWFUL HOUSING PRACTICES:
A. General: It shall be an unlawful housing practice and a violation of this chapter for any
person to participate in the following:
1. Aiding Violation: To aid, abet, incite, intimidate, or coerce a person to engage in an
unlawful practice or interfere with any person(s) in the exercise or enjoyment of
any right granted or protected by village ordinance.
2. Deceiving Practices: To deceive, exploit, cheat, or overcharge any person in a real
property transaction in the village, or to make any distinction, unlawful
discrimination, or restriction against any person as to the conditions or privileges of
any kind relating to the sale, rental, lease, or occupancy of any dwelling or real
property. To act as a real estate broker, salesperson, or agent with respect to any
dwelling or real property whose disposition requires said person(s) to participate in
unlawful discrimination.
3. Refusing Information: To deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of copies
of any listing of dwelling or real property in the village to any person because of
race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing status,
matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment.
4. Discriminatory Agreements: To enter into or maintain a listing agreement which
prohibits the inspection, sale, lease, or occupancy of dwelling or real property to
any person because of race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status,
housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment.
5. Discriminatory Disposition: To act or undertake to act with respect to any dwelling
or real property the disposition of which is prohibited to any person because of
race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing status,
matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment.
6. Interfering With Authority: To wilfully interfere with the performance of a duty or
the exercise of a power by the commission or one of its members or
representatives.
7. Obstructing Compliance: To wilfully obstruct or prevent a person from complying
with the provisions of this chapter or an order issued hereunder. (1969 Code
§ 156.205; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
8. Panic Peddling: To wilfully violate this chapter for the purpose of inducing, whether
for profit or not for profit, any other person to enter into a real estate transaction
with such person, his principal, or his agent:
a. To represent that a change has occurred, will occur, or may occur with respect
to race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability,
national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing
status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment in the
composition of the owners or occupants in any block, neighborhood, or area in
which the dwelling or real property (which is the subject of the real estate
transaction) is located, or
b. To represent that a change with respect to the race, color, gender, sexual
orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital
status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source
of income or any lawful rental payment in the composition of the owners or
occupants in any block, neighborhood, or area will result in the lowering of
property values, or in an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or in a
decline in the quality of schools, in such blocks, neighborhood, or area. (1969
Code § 156.200; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
9. Threatening Practices: To make deliberate or repeated unsolicited verbal
comments, gestures, or physical contact that make for an offensive environment.
No person shall intentionally create alarm among residents within the village by
transmitting communication in any manner designed to induce any person within
the village to participate in a real estate transaction within the village because of
the present or perspective entry into the vicinity of the property of any individual
or individuals of any particular race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military
status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental
payment.
10. Sexual Harassment: To make any unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual
favors, or conduct of a sexual nature when: a) submission to such conduct is an
explicit or implicit term or condition of any individual's real estate transaction; or
b) submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis
for any decision affecting the individual's real estate transaction; or c) such
conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's
real estate transaction or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive
environment with respect thereto.
B. Owner/Individual And Realtor Restrictions: It shall be an unlawful housing practice and
a violation of this chapter for any person or realtor to participate in the following:
1. Discriminating In The Sale Or Lease Of Property: To sell or lease a dwelling or real
property, on a public basis, on terms, conditions or privileges that discriminate
between persons because of race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military
status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental
payment. To impose different sale prices or rental charges for the sale or rental of
a dwelling upon any person because of race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age,
creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status,
military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any lawful
rental payment. (1969 Code § 156.050; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
2. Refusing To Negotiate: To refuse to negotiate for, enter into, or perform any sale or
lease of any dwelling or real property, on a public basis, because of the race, color,
gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
marital status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or
source of income or any lawful rental payment of any party to such sale or lease, or
of any member of the family of any such party, or of any person using or occupying
or intending to use or occupy such dwelling or real property or of any person using
or occupying any real property in the area in which such real property is located.
(1969 Code § 156.055; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
3. Refusing Offers: To receive or to fail to transmit a bona fide offer for the purchase,
sale, exchange, or lease, or to refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide
agreement for the purchase, sale, exchange, or lease of any dwelling or real
property because of the race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military
status, housing status, matriculation or source of income or any lawful rental
payment of the person making such an offer. (1969 Code § 156.105; amd. Ord.
03-22, 11-10-2003)
4. Delaying Rental Application: To discriminate by denying or unreasonably delaying
the processing of a lease or rental application of a person, discriminate in the fixing
of the fee or length of processing time, or other terms and conditions of such
application processes.
5. Withholding Housing: To represent, on a public basis to any person that any
dwelling or real property is not available for inspection, purchase, sale, lease, or
occupancy when in fact it is so available, or otherwise to withhold any dwelling or
real property from any person because of race, color, gender, sexual orientation,
age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial
status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any
lawful rental payment. (1969 Code § 156.060; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
6. Evicting: To evict tenants because of their race, color, gender, sexual orientation,
age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial
status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any
lawful rental payment, or because of the race, color, gender, sexual orientation,
age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status, familial
status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or any
lawful rental payment of a tenant's guest.
7. Blockbusting: To engage in blockbusting or encourage blockbusting by distributing
or causing to be distributed written material or statements designed to induce any
owner of a dwelling or real property in the village to sell or lease his, her, or its
property because of any prospective change in the race, color, gender, sexual
orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, marital status,
familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or source of income or
any lawful rental payment of individuals in the neighborhood.
8. Discriminating Due To Disability: To refuse to permit, at the expense of the
disabled person, reasonable modifications of an existing dwelling unit occupied or
to be occupied by such person if such modifications may be necessary to afford
such person full enjoyment of the premises; except that in the case of a rental, the
landlord may, where it is reasonable to do so, condition a permission for a
modification on the renter agreeing to restore the interior of the premises to the
condition that existed before the modification, reasonable wear and tear excepted
a person with disabilities may make reasonable modification as provided in this
section of the fair housing ordinance to the interior or exterior public and common
use areas of a building, as well as to his and her individual dwelling units. To refuse
to make reasonable accommodation in rules, policies, practices, or services when
such accommodations may be necessary to afford such person equal opportunity
to use and enjoy a dwelling or real property.
9. Steering: To engage in steering as defined in section 10-13-2 of this chapter.
10. Unlawful Advertisements: To, on a public basis, publish or circulate a statement,
advertisement, or notice, or cause to be published or circulated with respect to the
sale or lease of any dwelling or real property in a manner that is unlawful under
this section, or to consent thereto. (1969 Code § 156.065; amd. Ord. 03-22,
11-10-2003)
11. Unlawful Signs And Notices: To post or erect, or cause any person to post or erect
on a public basis, any sign or notice upon any dwelling or real property, indicating
an intent to sell or lease any dwelling or real property in a manner that is unlawful
under this section. (1969 Code § 156.070; amd. Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
12. Deceitful Appraisals: To discriminate in appraising the value of a dwelling or real
property or in the sale of insurance in connection with a real estate transaction of
any person(s).
13. Discriminatory Listing: To enter into a listing agreement which discriminates
against any person(s) or denies any person(s) access to, or membership or
participation in, any multiple listing service or real estate brokers' organization or
other service, organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting
dwellings; discriminating against any person(s) in the terms and conditions of such
access, membership, or participation.
14. Distributing: To fail to place in a prominent location available for observance by the
public in each business establishment of a person in the business of purchasing,
selling, exchanging, or leasing real property a copy of this chapter or a summary
thereof.
15. Limitations: Nothing in this chapter shall require an owner to offer a dwelling or
real property to the public at large before selling or renting it, providing he
complies with all other provisions of this chapter. Nor shall this chapter require an
owner or his agent to offer a dwelling or real property for sale or lease to any
person if the owner or his agent has reasonable cause which can be substantiated
to believe that such person is not negotiating for the purchase or lease of such real
property in good faith, nor shall this chapter be deemed to prohibit owners from
giving a preference to prospective tenants or buyers for any reason other than
race, color, gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, marital status, familial status, military status, housing status,
matriculation, or source of income or any lawful rental payment. Rental of no more
than two (2) rooms in an owner occupied single-family dwelling shall not be
included within the provisions of this chapter. (1969 Code § 156.075; amd. Ord.
03-22, 11-10-2003)
C. Lending Restrictions: It shall be an unlawful housing practice and a violation of this
chapter for any lender or lending institution to participate in the following:
1. Discrimination In Lending: To make, agree to make, arrange, or negotiate any loan
or guarantee of funds that discriminate between persons because of race, color,
gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
marital status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or
source of income or any lawful rental payment for the purpose of financing the
purchase or sale, construction, lease, rehabilitation, improvement, renovation, or
repair of any dwelling or real estate; to discriminate in the fixing of the amount,
interest rate, duration, or other terms or conditions of such loans or other financial
assistance.
2. Refusals To Deal In Lending: To refuse to negotiate for, enter into, or perform or
delay the processing of any agreement to lend or guarantee the loan of funds for
the purchase, sale, construction, lease, maintenance, rehabilitation, improvement,
renovation, or repair of any dwelling or real property because of race, color,
gender, sexual orientation, age, creed, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
marital status, familial status, military status, housing status, matriculation, or
source of income or any lawful rental payment of any party to such agreement, or
of any member of the family of any such party, or of the residents of the area in
which such dwelling or real property is located. (1969 Code § 156.075; amd. Ord.
03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-5: EXEMPTIONS:
Unlawful housing practices as listed above shall not apply to the following instances:
A. The rental, lease, or occupancy of a room in an owner occupied single-family dwelling
having not more than two (2) roomers living independently exclusive of salaried
household employees living on premises;
B. Limitation by a religious organization, association, or society (or any not for profit
institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by, or in conjunction with,
a religious organization, association, or society) of the sale, rental, or occupancy of a
dwelling which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to individuals
of the same religion, or from giving preference to such individuals;
C. Prohibiting a private club, not in fact open to the public, which as incident to its
primary purpose or purposes, provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than
a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its
members and their guests or from giving preference to its members;
D. Prohibiting the operation of housing units designed and offered predominantly for use
and occupancy by persons fifty five (55) years of age or older;
E. Prohibiting the operation of housing units designed and offered predominantly for use
and occupancy by persons with disabilities;
F. Prohibiting any charitable or educational organization from limiting to persons of the
same sex the rental of living accommodations and facilities primarily providing single
room occupancy;
G. Prohibiting an initial condominium declaration limiting ownership, rental, or occupancy
of a condominium unit to a person fifty five (55) years of age or older, provided that
the person or immediate family of a person owning, renting, or lawfully occupying such
unit prior to the recording of the initial declaration shall not be deemed to be in
violation of such age restriction as long as they continue to own or reside in such
housing accommodation;
H. Not withstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, nothing contained
in section 10-13-4 of this chapter shall require any person who does not participate in
the federal section 8 housing assistance program (42 USC 1437f) to accept any
subsidy, payment assistance, voucher or contribution under or in connection with this
program or to lease or rent to any tenant or prospective tenant who is relying on such
a subsidy, payment assistance, contribution, or voucher for payment of part of the rent
for such housing accommodation unless the prospective tenant has good credit history,
good tenant history and sufficient income and does not have a history of drug usage or
a criminal record. (Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-6: COMPLAINT PROCEDURE:
The rules contained in the new "Robert's Rules Of Order" shall govern in all cases in which
they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with this chapter or the special
rules of order as set forth below.
A. Filing Of Complaint:
1. Any person(s) aggrieved in any manner by a violation of any provision of this
chapter may file with the village administrator a written complaint setting forth the
grievance within ninety (90) days after the date of the alleged violation. The
complaint shall state: a) the name and address of the complainant, b) the name
and address of the person against whom the complaint is brought, if known to the
complainant, and c) the alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation of this
chapter; and such complaint shall state the name and address of all persons
believed to have knowledge concerning the alleged acts. The complaint shall be
filed on the form provided by the commission and available in the office of the
village administrator.
2. The village administrator shall notify the chair of the community relations
commission and the staff liaison to the commission of the complaint. The chair of
the community relations commission shall notify the chair of the fair housing
committee to set a committee conference to review the complaint after the
"preliminary fact finding" is completed.
B. Preliminary Fact Finding:
1. The chair of the fair housing committee shall contact the complainant by telephone
within five (5) business days of the filing for review and elaboration of the
information contained in the written complaint. If the complainant cannot be
contacted by telephone within the five (5) business day period, a certified letter,
return receipt requested, shall be sent indicating the necessity for the complainant
to communicate with the chair within five (5) business days of the receipt of the
certified letter or the complaint shall be deemed to be withdrawn.
2. After speaking with the complainant the chair of the fair housing committee shall
determine whether the complaint describes an action which may be a violation of
the fair housing ordinance according to the procedure set forth below:
a. If the chair of the fair housing committee believes the complaint is deemed to
possibly have merit:
(1) The chair of the fair housing committee shall attempt to contact the
respondent by telephone within five (5) business days after contact with the
complainant to notify the respondent that a complaint has been filed.
Subsequently, the chair of the fair housing committee shall provide the
respondent a copy of the filed complaint via certified mail, return receipt
requested, and request a written response on the form provided within
seven (7) business days via trackable mail. If the chair cannot contact the
respondent by telephone within five (5) business days, contact will be
attempted by certified mail, return receipt requested, with response
required within seven (7) business days after receipt of the certified letter. If
the certified letter is undeliverable, messenger service of the
communication will be utilized and the respondent will be given seven (7)
business days to respond in writing to the attention of the chair of the fair
housing committee. Finally, the complainant shall be advised to seek the
assistance of either state or federal fair housing agencies to further
prosecute their complaint.
(2) The chair of the fair housing committee shall recontact the complainant with
a status report should the attempt to obtain a response from the respondent
be delayed. Within five (5) business days after receipt of written response
from the respondent, the chair will provide the complainant a copy of the
respondent's response and discuss the information obtained from the
respondent in a personal meeting with each party.
(3) If the complainant determines within seven (7) business days that the
respondent's response resolves the complaint, the complainant will be
asked to withdraw the complaint by signing the complaint form as directed.
Two (2) copies of the form will be sent to the complainant by certified mail,
with the request that one copy be executed and returned to the village for
its records within fifteen (15) business days of receipt of the forms. If the
form is not returned by the thirtieth day after the form has been received,
the matter will be considered resolved and shall be so noted on the original
complaint form.
(4) When the complaint is withdrawn, the chair will notify the respondent in
writing within five (5) business days. The chair shall report on the complaint
disposition to the full commission at the next regularly scheduled meeting.
(5) If the complainant determines within seven (7) business days that the
respondent's response is not satisfactory, the chair shall take both the
complaint and the response to the fair housing committee within seven (7)
business days of receipt of the written response from the respondent for
verification that a violation of the fair housing ordinance may have been
committed.
(6) Following verification that a violation of the fair housing ordinance has been
committed and the chair of the fair housing committee believes that the
activity prompting the complaint will continue to occur, he/she shall relay
such evidence to the board of trustees within five (5) business days,
together with a recommendation that the corporation counsel be instructed
to seek injunctive relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to prohibit such
violation. Upon receipt of the chair's recommendation, the board shall make
a determination within five (5) business days. If the board concurs with the
chair's recommendation, the board shall instruct the corporation counsel to
seek immediate injunctive relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to
prohibit such violation.
(7) If the fair housing committee concurs that a violation of the fair housing
ordinance may have occurred, a conciliation conference shall be scheduled
no less than ten (10) business days nor more than thirty (30) days from the
conclusion of the fact finding (see subsection C of this section).
b. If the chair of the fair housing committee believes that the complaint describes
an action which is not considered to be a violation of the fair housing ordinance:
(1) The chair of the fair housing committee shall meet with the fair housing
committee within ten (10) business days of the contact with the
complainant to render a final decision if a violation of the fair housing
ordinance has occurred.
(2) If the fair housing committee concurs that a violation did not occur, all
further action shall terminate with notice to the complainant by certified
mail. After such notice, the complainant shall petition the community
relations commission as a whole for review of the findings of the committee.
(3) If the fair housing committee believes that a violation did occur, it shall
direct its chair to complete the fact finding (as described in this section).
C. Conciliation Conference:
1. The chair of the fair housing committee shall notify all community relations
commission members that a conciliation conference will be scheduled within thirty
(30) days from the conclusion of the preliminary fact finding. The chair of the fair
housing committee and up to two (2) additional commission members shall
comprise the conciliation conference panel in an effort to resolve the complaint
issues in private. The corporation counsel shall be an ex officio member of the
conciliation conference panel. The village administrator and the staff liaison to the
community relations commission and the trustee appointed as commission liaison
may also be in attendance. The complainant and the respondent shall be notified in
writing of the date, time, and place of the conciliation conference at least seven (7)
business days in advance of the conference.
2. Both the complainant and respondent must be present at the conference. In the
event that either party refuses to participate and their testimony is relevant to the
investigation, the commission may exercise its power to subpoena said
individual(s). If any witness resides outside the state or, through illness or any
other cause, is unable to testify before the commission, or its members or agents
conducting the hearing or investigation, that witness' testimony or deposition may
be taken within or outside of the state, in such manner and in such form as the
commission may prescribe. The complainant and the respondent may each be
represented by up to two (2) additional individuals who may be attorneys. If either
the complainant or the respondent is an organization, a maximum of three (3)
persons representing the organization, including attorneys, shall be allowed.
The conference shall be closed to all other persons except those included in
subsection C1 of this section.
3. The chair of the fair housing committee shall preside at the conference and rule on
all questions of order. The general format of the conciliation conference is as
described below:
a. Chair's Opening Statement: The chair's explanation of the process, the
procedures that will be followed, and the goal of the session.
b. Parties' Statements: An opportunity for all parties present to explain the reason
they have been invited to the conciliation conference and what their initial
desired outcomes are. Initial statements should be limited to fifteen (15)
minutes for the complainant and respondent, respectively.
c. Identifying The Issues: The chair outlines a joint list of the issues both parties
have raised for conciliation.
d. Cross Talk: A period during which the conciliation panel attempts to clarify the
positions and needs of the parties and works with the parties to explore
possible points of agreement. It is also a time when options are both tested and
generated. This stage usually occurs both before and after caucus.
e. Caucus: Private, confidential meetings between the conciliation panel and
individual parties or groupings of parties as decided by the chair.
f. Concluding The Conciliation: The stage at which the chair decides to stop the
conciliation conference. Either an agreement has been reached or the chair has
determined there is no further progress to be made.
4. No evidence shall be taken at the conciliation conference. The sole purpose of the
conference will be to attempt to reconcile the parties. Minutes of the conference
shall be taken which identify the persons present, the complaint filed and the
outcome of the conference.
5. In the event that the parties reach agreement at the conciliation conference, both
parties shall sign the agreement as described on the complaint form which
stipulates that the complaint is resolved and that no subsequent action will be
taken on this complaint.
6. In the event that the parties cannot reach agreement at the conciliation
conference, the chair shall schedule a conciliation hearing where testimony shall
be taken under oath and which will conclude with a formal recommendation to the
board of trustees.
7. Members of the commission, village officials, or village staff shall not disclose the
filing of a complaint, information gathered during the course of an investigation, or
testimony which may have been presented during the course of a conciliation,
except as such disclosures are deemed essential to said investigation and
endeavors at conciliation, or are made at an open session. Nothing in this
paragraph shall be construed to prevent the commission from disclosing dismissal
notices or conciliation agreements, including the reasons therefor. The identities of
the parties to the complaint shall not be disclosed without their consent.
D. Conciliation Hearing:
1. A conciliation hearing will be scheduled by the chair of the fair housing committee
if reconciliation of the complaint cannot be resolved at the conciliation conference.
The date, time, and place for the hearing shall be within thirty (30) days from the
conclusion of the conciliation conference. The complainant and the respondent
shall be notified in writing of the date, time, and place of the conciliation hearing at
least seven (7) business days in advance of the hearing.
2. The chair of the fair housing committee shall complete a written report to the
commission as to the need to hold a conciliation hearing which shall not be open to
the public. The chair of the commission shall call a special meeting of the
commission at which a motion, which specifies that a meeting to discuss fair
housing matters, shall be made to conduct a closed conciliation hearing. The vote
of each member of the commission on this motion must be recorded.
3. The conciliation hearing panel will be comprised of the chair of the fair housing
committee and four (4) other voting members of the community relations
commission, the village administrator, the staff liaison to the commission, the
corporation counsel, and the trustee appointed as commission liaison. An alternate
shall be appointed by the chair of the fair housing committee to replace any voting
member unable to serve. Only members of the community relations commission
shall be authorized to vote on matters before the conciliation hearing panel.
4. The chair of the fair housing committee shall preside at the conciliation hearing
and rule on all questions of order.
5. A quorum is required to conduct all sessions of a conciliation hearing. If a quorum
is not present throughout an entire session, at the time that a quorum ceases to
exist, the chair of the fair housing committee shall issue a continuance of the
conciliation hearing. A quorum shall consist of three (3) of the members of the
commission, including the chair of the fair housing committee.
6. All parties shall be entitled to legal representation at the conciliation hearing.
7. Testimony given at the conciliation hearing shall be given under oath or affirmation
which is administered by the chair of the fair housing committee.
8. The conciliation hearing will proceed in the following manner and in accordance
with the open meetings act:
a. Both the complainant and respondent must be present at the conference. In the
event that either party refuses to participate and their testimony is relevant to
the investigation, the commission may exercise its power to subpoena said
individual(s). If any witness resides out of the state or, through illness or any
other cause, is unable to testify before the commission, or its members or
agents conducting the hearing or investigation, that witness' testimony or
deposition may be taken within or outside of the state, in such manner and in
such form as the commission may prescribe. The complainant and the
respondent may each be represented by up to two (2) additional individuals
who may be attorneys. If either the complainant or the respondent is an
organization, a maximum of three (3) persons representing the organization,
including attorneys, shall be allowed.
b. The conciliation hearing will be called to order by the chair of the fair housing
committee, roll will be taken, and the complaint shall be read aloud. The
conciliation hearing shall be recorded electronically, and minutes shall be taken
by a recording secretary.
c. After reviewing aloud the rules and procedures governing the conciliation
hearing, the chair of the fair housing committee will entertain opening
statements of fifteen (15) minutes or less by both parties. The complainant's
statement will be given first.
d. After opening statements are made by both parties, the complainant or their
legal representatives will be asked to present their case to the panel. The
complainant can call witnesses and submit evidence. Each witness will be
subject to cross examination by the respondent or their legal representatives.
e. Upon completion of the complainant's case to the panel, the respondent or their
legal representatives will be asked to present their case. The respondent or
their legal representatives can call witnesses and submit evidence. Each
witness will be subject to cross examination by the complainant or their legal
representatives.
f. Panel members may also ask questions of the witnesses.
g. At the conclusion of the testimony, each party will be entitled to a closing
statement of five (5) minutes. The complainant's closing statement will be
followed by the respondent's.
h. The chair of the fair housing committee will recess the conciliation hearing, and
the panel will retire to executive session to deliberate the complaint. The chair
of the fair housing committee shall preside at the executive session. Final
recommendations will be voted on in open session. A majority vote of panel
members present empowered to vote will be required to render a
recommendation to the board of trustees.
I. After the vote is recorded, the chair of the fair housing committee will
reconvene the conciliation hearing, at which time the recommendation
(including findings of fact) shall be provided to the complainant and respondent
orally. Subsequently, within thirty (30) days after the close of the conciliation
hearing, the complainant and respondent will receive the recommendation
(including findings of fact) in writing.
j. The panel's recommendation (including findings of fact) will be summarized in
writing and reported to the board of trustees by the chair of the fair housing
committee within thirty (30) days after the close of the conciliation hearing.
(Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-7: SANCTIONS; PENALTIES:
A. In the event that the panel finds that no fair housing discriminatory act or practice
occurred, the panel will recommend to the board of trustees that the complaint be
dismissed.
B. If the panel finds that a violation has occurred in the area of fair housing, the panel
may recommend to the board of trustees that the corporation counsel be directed to
take action, including, but not limited to: (Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
1. Imposition of a fine in accordance with title 1, chapter 4 of this code for each
offense, in addition to payment of all costs incurred by the village. Each day a
violation continues may be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 08-22, 5-12-2008)
2. Direction to apply to the circuit court of Cook County or to the federal courts:
a. For an order restraining the party or parties from violating any provision of this
chapter, or
b. For such other or further relief as may be appropriate for the enforcement of
this chapter.
3. Other relief determined to be appropriate. (Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
10-13-8: LEGAL REMEDIES:
Any person aggrieved in any manner by the violation of any provision of this chapter,
regardless of the findings of the procedures described in this chapter, who has exhausted the
remedies provided in this chapter may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for
appropriate relief from such violation, including, but not limited to:
A. An order compelling compliance with this chapter.
B. An order to prohibit any person found by the court to have violated any provision of
this chapter from the sale, lease, exchange, transfer, conveyance, or assignment of
any dwelling or real property by any person who, in violation of this chapter, refuses or
fails to perform such contract.
C. Compensatory damages.
D. In a civil action under this chapter, the court may allow the prevailing party a
reasonable attorney fees and costs.
E. Such other and further relief as deemed appropriate by the court for the enforcement
of this chapter and the elimination of violations hereof. (1969 Code § 156.305; amd.
Ord. 03-22, 11-10-2003)
Chapter 14
STANDARDS FOR BOARDING UP VACANT AND OCCUPIED
STRUCTURES IN ALL ZONING DISTRICTS
10-14-1: BOARD UP REQUEST; PERMIT REQUIRED:
From time to time in order to protect a structure from the elements or to ensure the security
of a structure the owner or the owner's agent may deem it appropriate to board up windows
or door openings. Prior to boarding up the window or door openings in any vacant or occupied
structure located in any zoning district, the owner and/or the owner's agent shall contact the
building department and request a permit to install boarding under the procedures and
standards outlined in this chapter. The building commissioner shall review all requests to
board up the door and window openings in structures and shall issue a permit, therefore, only
under the procedures and standards established in this chapter. Should damage occur to a
structure during the nighttime hours, on weekends or at other times when the building
commissioner is not available, the owner or the owner's agent may apply boarding as
provided for in this chapter provided that application is made for a permit during the first
business day following the board up action. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-2: BOARD UP PERMIT; REVIEW PROCEDURES; ISSUANCE OR
DENIAL:
The building commissioner shall review each board up permit application to determine the
potential for vandalism, structural damage due to exposure to rain, wind and other elements
of nature, the security of the structure, the overall security and aesthetic impact on the
neighborhood and the need to provide light and ventilation for occupants. If the building
commissioner agrees following his investigation that boarding up some or all of the window
and door openings in a structure will best serve to protect the structure, the safety and
welfare of the occupants, and the overall safety and security of the neighborhood, a board up
permit shall be issued to the owner or the owner's agent and work may commence
immediately to board up the structure under the standards established in this chapter. If
however, the building commissioner determines that boarding up window and door openings
is not necessary to protect the structure, or may threaten the health, safety and welfare of
residents or may adversely impact the neighborhood, a board up permit shall be denied and
the owner or the owner's agent shall be instructed to proceed immediately with normal
window and door repairs so that the structure will remain safe and secure and impervious to
the elements. Such repairs to be accomplished as provided for in the relevant sections of this
code. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-3: BOARD UP PERMIT; DURATION; EXTENSION:
No board up permit shall be issued for a period greater than one hundred twenty (120) days.
The owner or the owner's agent of a structure that has been boarded up at window or door
who anticipates a need to have the boarding remain for a period in excess of one hundred
twenty (120) days shall in writing to the building department request an extension of the
board up permit. Each extension request shall include a detailed explanation of why the
construction and/or reconstruction, repair and reoccupancy of the building cannot be
accomplished within the original one hundred twenty (120) day permit period and include a
time table as to when the construction, repair or reoccupancy will occur. The building
commissioner after reviewing a request for an extension of a board up permit may grant the
requested extension for a period not to exceed sixty (60) additional days. Under extraordinary
circumstances, in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, the building
commissioner may grant monthly extensions of the board up permit thereafter. The building
commissioner shall forward copies of all board up permit extension requests along with any
relevant information regarding the request or the building commissioner's findings regarding
whether or not an extension of the permit should be granted to the appearance commission.
(Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-4: BOARD UP OF WINDOWS AND DOORS; WHEN REQUIRED:
When necessary for causes due to wind damage, fire, vandalism or accident, the building
commissioner may order any part or all of the openings at window and door of a structure to
be securely boarded as per the standards provided for in this chapter. Whenever the building
commissioner deems it necessary that all of, or portions of the building be boarded at window
or door, written notice shall be provided to the owner or the owner's agent advising that the
building must be secure within seventy two (72) hours as shall be deemed appropriate under
the circumstances by the building commissioner. A board up order shall be issued on a
standardized form similar to the form used for granting board up permits and shall contain the
relevant information regarding the one hundred twenty (120) day time period which shall
constitute the normal permit period under the provisions of this chapter. The owner and/or the
owner's agent shall also be notified of the repairs required to the structure so that the
boarding can be removed at the appropriate time as well as the procedure for securing an
extension of the board up permit should circumstances warrant. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-5: EMERGENCY BOARD UP PROVISIONS:
On occasion the building commissioner may determine that a vacant structure open at door or
window poses a significant threat to the health and welfare of any person who might enter
upon the premises. The commissioner is hereby authorized to provide the owner or the
owner's agent with written or verbal notice that the building must be secured through board
up or repair of existing door and windows within twenty four (24) hours of the notice. Should
the owner or the owner's agent of a vacant structure, determined by the building
commissioner to be an emergency hazard fail to respond within the twenty four (24) hour
period of time the building commissioner shall be authorized to have the building secured by
village forces or outside contractors, the cost to be borne by the property owner. In such
event, the cost of such boarding shall be and constitute a lien upon such real estate upon
notice of same being recorded at the office of the recorder of deeds or registered at the office
of the registrar of titles. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-6: BOARD UP STANDARDS:
All exterior openings to buildings boarded up under the provisions of this chapter shall be
completed in a neat and workmanlike manner with not less than one-half inch (1/2") thick
weather resistant plywood cut to fit within the openings. The plywood shall be securely
fastened in place, and suitably coated with an appropriate neutral color which will have the
effect of blending the board up material with or complementing the existing exterior colors of
the building. The coating applied shall render the boarding used to cover door and window
openings as inconspicuous as possible. Boarding up work once commenced following issuance
of a permit, shall be completed, including the application of an appropriate, neutral color to
the exterior side of the boarding material without delay or interruption. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-7: NOTICE OF NONCOMPLIANCE:
It shall be the duty of the building commissioner to notify the owner or the agent of any
vacant structure not complying with the above requirements of the necessity for compliance
and providing written notice requiring the timely compliance with the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-14-8: PENALTY:
A responsible owner or agent of owner or occupant of such real estate shall be subject to a
penalty in accordance with title 1, chapter 4 of this code for each day such violation exists
following the expiration time as specified in any notice either written or verbal issued by the
building commissioner requiring compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 08-22,
5-12-2008)
Chapter 15
APPEARANCE CODE
The Appearance Code has been replaced by Title 12, Chapter 12 per Ord. 07-07, 3-26-2007.
Chapter 16
ANTENNAS AND ANTENNA SUPPORT STRUCTURES
10-16-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: It is hereby required that a permit be obtained in advance and that all
requirements of the building code, electric code, zoning ordinance, and other relative
and applicable ordinances be complied with whenever an antenna or antenna support
structure is erected, installed, altered, or structurally repaired; except that no permit
shall be required if the height of the antenna and antenna support structure (excluding
the height of any building to which the antenna support structure is attached) is less
than eighteen feet (18') high.
B. Submittals Required: Five (5) copies of the following submittals shall be included with
the permit application:
1. Current plat of survey for the parcel where the antenna and antenna support
structure will be located.
2. A site plan, including the location of the antenna support structure, location of any
ancillary antenna equipment, location of structures on adjacent lots, location of
overhead electric wires, and type and location of required visual screening.
3. Manufacturer's specifications for the antenna and antenna support structure
including structural details and calculations required by this chapter.
4. Construction plans for any ancillary equipment buildings shall be sealed by an
Illinois registered architect or Illinois registered structural engineer. (Ord. 85-1,
1-25-1985)
10-16-2: LOCATION ON PARCEL:
Permitted locations on a zoning lot and number of antennas permitted on a zoning lot, shall be
in accordance with the Morton Grove zoning ordinance. (Ord. 85-1, 1-25-1985)
10-16-3: CONSTRUCTION:
A. Material: Antenna support structures shall be constructed of approved corrosion resistant
noncombustible material.
B. Design Loads:
1. All antenna and antenna support structures shall be designed to withstand a wind
velocity of ninety (90) miles per hour without use of supporting guywires; design
wind gust factor shall be 1.3.
2. Antenna support structures shall be designed for the "dead load" of the support
structure, antennas, and at least one-half inch (1/2") of radial ice.
